Its eponymous heroine was raisedIola Leroy is a late 19th century novel largely taking place in the South during and immediately after the Civil War. Its eponymous heroine was raised believing she was white, although she had a grandparent who was Black. When her father died, her world was upended and she and her mother were sold into slavery. Rather than attempting to pass or marry into white society, her family proudly identified with and became part of the Black community. Iola Leroy is not much of a novel (thus the above is not really spoilers); instead, it reads more like a series of scenes in an abolitionist's play or a script for a debate. “But, Johnson, you do not look like them, you do not talk like them. It is a burning shame to have held such a man as you in slavery.” “I don’t think it was any worse to have held me in slavery than the blackest man in the South.” (p. 40)Some of Frances E. W. Harper's arguments remain current, as this dialogue could profitably be read by Gov. DeSantis and some other US politicians:"I have often heard that colored people are ungrateful, but I don’t think Tom’s worst enemy would say that about him.” “Captain,” said Robert, with a tone of bitterness in his voice, “what had we to be grateful for? For ages of poverty, ignorance, and slavery? I think if anybody should be grateful, it is the people who have enslaved us and lived off our labor for generations." She argued in 1861 that African American writers should write about more than politics and slavery, as doing so limited their vocabulary: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Qoa-i... review: What is true? And how do you know? (p. 144)When I was in high school, I was full of questions like these. I wondered whether you and I saw the same c What is true? And how do you know? (p. 144)When I was in high school, I was full of questions like these. I wondered whether you and I saw the same color as red. I wondered whether what was true for me was also true for you. The adults I knew didn't know what to make of such questions and mostly dismissed them. What would it have been like to have a teacher, like Sarah Viren's Dr. Whiles, who took those questions seriously and helped students develop the skills to question the nature of reality and the stories people tell about them.As Viren observed, while this questioning is a useful and important skill to develop, it can also be a dangerous teaching strategy if not handled well (e.g., the difference between the philosophical freshman year Dr. Whiles and the conspiracy-filled junior year version). Against this backdrop, Viren described the story of her partner – and eventually Viren, herself – being (falsely) accused of sexual harassment by several anonymous students. How does one believe – and we encourage people to believe victims – and fight back? How does one go through this without it damaging one's career, family, and friendships? Viren's story is about truth and survival, but it's about more: Would I have been able to distinguish truth from fears from propaganda? Would I have sided with Socrates? Or those standing beside and among me who wanted to put him to death? The question of justice inherent to those calculations no longer seemed all that abstract. Neither Dr. Whiles nor Jay was a figure like Socrates—I knew that—but I still felt myself, both audience member and author of this much smaller drama, wanting not only to know what was true but also what was just. (p. 158). Dr. Whiles' story alone would make a thrilling book, but it becomes a thought-provoking one when seen against both the political times in the US, which she only briefly talked about, and her history as Dr. Whiles' student. Aren't we always looking at our world through a glass distorted by what happened earlier? Viren clearly recognized this duality, what Virginia Woolf called the "I now" and the "I then," and that each influences the other. I am my history, my history is seen through my present eyes. I wouldn't have read The Bigger Lie if it had been a novel, as most thrillers feel far-fetched. The Bigger Lie is far-fetched, but sometimes far-fetched is true. I felt paranoid along with Viren, worried about how students (or professional enemies) might spread rumors that would hurt me and my family. Not far-fetched in these times.One narrative that analysts tell about conspiracies is that those subscribing to conspiracy theories are less well-educated and less intellectually-gifted. One of the interesting things is that Dr. Whiles was clearly thoughtful and well-read, yet fell down a conspiracy rabbit hole, taking a number of his students with him. Subscribing to conspiracy theories is about more than poor critical thinking skills.Viren originally published this story in the New York Times. The original story is compelling, the intertwined stories are so much more....more

She also clearly outlined how out of control her behavior had been between ages 11-16, but also observed how clueless she had been as she tried to support herself, traverse relationships, and stay safe. Part of her recovery involved traveling the world, both out of curiosity, but also her work as a journalist working on human rights issues. As a result, "One trip after another, we met people who had survived unimaginable horror, endured beyond what seemed humanly capable. Slowly, I was learning of the bottomless capacity for both human cruelty and human survival" (p. 238). I read No Visible Bruises earlier this year. my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: One of the difficulties with (reading) history is that we can get a sanitized and flattened narrative. That narrative can focus on Great Men, people (One of the difficulties with (reading) history is that we can get a sanitized and flattened narrative. That narrative can focus on Great Men, people (men) in power, wars and diplomacy, etc. It often doesn't focus on new immigrants, the underclass, women, and the contradictions in their experiences. In Buddha in the Attic, Julie Otsuka provides a short history of early 20th century "picture brides" from Japan, not by describing the typical experience (was there a typical experience???), but by giving a range of experiences and asking the reader to abstract a central quality, much like a pointillist painting (e.g., Georges Seurat). Otsuka had started her career as a painter. Was that her intention?Here Otsuka describes the panic following Pearl Harbor, but before Japanese immigrants and their American-born children and grandchildren were interned in concentration camps:It was nearly impossible to get your name on the list. It was extremely easy to get your name on the list. Only people who belonged to our race were on the list. There were Germans and Italians on the list, but their names appeared toward the bottom. The list was written in indelible red ink. The list was typewritten on index cards. The list did not exist. The list existed, but only in the mind of the director of military intelligence, who was known for his perfect recall. The list was a figment of our imaginations. The list contained over five hundred names. The list contained over five thousand names. The list was endless. Every time an arrest was made another name was crossed off the list. Every time a name was crossed off the list a new name was added to it. New names were added to the list daily. Weekly. Hourly. (pp. 83-84)Otsuka's paragraphs captured the diversity of opinions, approaches, beliefs, and responses of the picture brides, but she often used the first person plural, "we" – although not in the examples here. Perhaps as they became acculturated into the more individualistic American society, their voices and experiences were named for the first time later in the book. "There was an old man from Gilroy who left on a stretcher. There was another old man—Natsuko’s husband, a retired barber in Florin—who left on crutches with an American Legion cap pulled down low over his head. 'Nobody win war. Everybody lose,' he said. Most of us left speaking only English, so as not to anger the crowds that had gathered to watch us go" (p. 105). Buddha in the Attic feels like poetry – broad and simple strokes carrying deeper levels of meaning. Imagine a different, non-contradictory list of suggestions for how to interact with white Americans. Would it be as effective? Would it tell us as much about this group and that time? Stay away from them, we were warned. Approach them with caution, if you must. Do not always believe what they tell you, but learn to watch them closely: their hands, their eyes, the corners of their mouths, sudden changes in the color of their skin. You will soon be able to read them. Make sure, however, that you don’t stare. With time you will grow accustomed to their largeness. Expect the worst, but do not be surprised by moments of kindness. There is goodness all around. Remember to make them feel comfortable. Be humble. Be polite. Appear eager to please. Say “Yes, sir,” or “No, sir,” and do as you’re told. Better yet, say nothing at all. You now belong to the invisible world. (pp. 25-26)Buddha in the Attic was moving in a way that I found unexpected. Some of its power came from subsuming many voices into a single, richly-textured braid....more

review: "Learning to live with—and sometimes love—one’s monsters while not letting them rule" us, is Sarah Rose Cavanagh's goal with Mind over Monsters (p. 22"Learning to live with—and sometimes love—one’s monsters while not letting them rule" us, is Sarah Rose Cavanagh's goal with Mind over Monsters (p. 226). Although she wrote for faculty working with high school and college students, her observations and suggestions are equally useful for other people working with students in this age group and for other people struggling with anxiety and depression.Mind over Monsters presents a wider range of suggestions for preventing anxiety from ruling us than I had expected, especially as she did not explicitly discuss challenging automatic thoughts – at least in the ways that a clinical psychologist would do. She used psychological research, interviews with students and experts in the field, and her personal experiences (she has had panic attacks and periods of selective mutism) to describe a nuanced way to handle anxiety successfully and handle high school college well. Bottom line, she recommends compassionate challenge, with equal emphasis on both compassion and challenge and makes a compelling case for this approach to teaching (or working with this age group).Among many other things, Cavanagh discussed going toward achievable tasks rather than avoiding them, matching anxiety to the task, recognizing that not all anxiety is a monster, supporting physical health and safety, learning to accept that some discomfort is normal (and health-guiding), and creating warm and safe environments (not cushioning). Adults need to create challenging but achievable environments, where students can succeed with appropriate work. She argued that "accommodating the student’s anxiety permanently also communicates that the anxiety is a core feature of the person, that it isn’t malleable or subject to change" (p. 51). Instead, we should be communicating, "I think you’re amazing. I think you are so smart, and so strong. Let’s do this together. I am here to support you” (p. 115). I enjoyed Mind over Monsters a lot. Cavanagh is a clear and entertaining storyteller who offers strong and compelling examples. She's a bit like me as a gardener: she likes a bit of chaos rather than a well-tended formal garden. This isn't entirely true, as her chapters are well-ordered and organized, just that they travel in such unexpected directions that I wasn't always able to summarize them afterwards, even though I had been familiar with the research she'd discussed beforehand....more

review: R. F. Kuang lambastes authors, the publishing system, readers of GR and Twitter, and everyone and everything else in Yellowface. She has an unreliableR. F. Kuang lambastes authors, the publishing system, readers of GR and Twitter, and everyone and everything else in Yellowface. She has an unreliable narrator, June Haywood, who is whiney and unlikeable, sees the people around her as getting unfair advantages (Haywood is the kind of white Progressive that DiAngelo was talking about in Nice Racism), and sets up a variety of problematic interactions as a result. I felt dirty spending time with June – and the people in her world – and yet I kept reading. A long hot shower was in order after finishing this book that had not a single unmitigated good guy.A three sentence summary: Brilliant, talented, and beautiful Athena Liu choked on a pancake and died. June Haywood – not as BTB as Liu – "lifted" Liu's unfinished manuscript and finished it. BTW, Haywood is white, writing a book about Chinese laborers in WWI.You may not agree with everything here (I don't), but she's right that the road to success can be unfair. Publishing picks a winner—someone attractive enough, someone cool and young and, oh, we’re all thinking it, let’s just say it, “diverse” enough—and lavishes all its money and resources on them. It’s so fucking arbitrary. Or perhaps not arbitrary, but it hinges on factors that have nothing to do with the strength of one’s prose. Athena—a beautiful, Yale-educated, international, ambiguously queer woman of color—has been chosen by the Powers That Be. (pp. 5-6)Haywood avoids blame and justifies everything she does, "It’s not like I took a painting and passed it off as my own. I inherited a sketch, with colors added only in uneven patches, and finished it according to the style of the original. Imagine if Michelangelo left huge chunks of the Sistine Chapel unfinished. Imagine if Raphael had to step in and do the rest" (p. 36). She sees herself as knowledgeable enough to write a Chinese history, but her understanding is very thin: "it’s important to be anti-PRC (that’s the People’s Republic of China) but pro-China (I’m not terribly sure how that’s different)" (p. 71). And Haywood recognizes Liu's brilliance, but also puts her down, "The original draft made you feel dumb, alienated at times, and frustrated with the self-righteousness of it all. It stank of all the most annoying things about Athena. The new version is a universally relatable story, a story that anyone can see themselves in" (p. 45). That is, "universally relatable" if you're white. And, she's most racist when protesting it. As one er in the text said: she "uses the suffering of thousands of Chinese laborers as a site for melodrama and white redemption” rather than as an opportunity to excavate a forgotten history (p. 99). Okay, I don't need to tell you more, except that everyone piles on building a good product, loving the book, then hating it, then hating Haywood. Accusations fly, with interesting questions all the way around. (If someone tells you their personal story and you use it in a story you publish, is that also theft?)The truth is fluid. There is always another way to spin the story, another wrench to throw into the narrative. review: Cutting for Stone is a massive book, almost 700 pages. I read it in fewer than four days, often in large gulps. Fifty-two percent of GR ers rateCutting for Stone is a massive book, almost 700 pages. I read it in fewer than four days, often in large gulps. Fifty-two percent of GR ers rate Cutting for Stone five stars, 15% three or fewer. I am in the former group. I loved Cutting for Stone. I love epics and the space they allow us to observe personal, cultural, and historical changes, especially when they cover three continents, as this does, although time on each continent is not equal. I wouldn't have imagined that I would have followed – and enjoyed – Abraham Verghese's lengthy descriptions of medical decisions and procedures and of Ethiopian politics. I did. I love reading/watching anything that one does with passion. They are also compassionate, thoughtful, and sometimes downright funny.The five major figures in this book are surgeons and passionate about their work. The narrator is one of a pair of conjoined twins, Marion and Shiva Praise Stone, who were separated at birth, and born to a nun who died in childbirth. Their purported father abandoned them shortly after their mother's death, and they were adopted and raised by a pair of loving and joyful physicians in their Mission Hospital (called "Missing" by all). Many of Verghese's points were made through stories and aphorisms. (Many people parent this way, right?) One important story was the Abu Kassem story: a miserly merchant held onto his battered, much repaired slippers, despite them being objects of derision and hateful even to himself, yet every attempt to get rid of them led to disaster. Everything we see, do, and touch, every seed we sow or don’t sow, becomes part of our destiny. (view spoiler)["Shiva, do you see how deflowering Genet, a biological act as far as you were concerned, led to all this? It led Rosina to kill herself, led Genet to stray from us? author: Herman, Judith Lewis
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: When the events are natural disasters or “acts of God,” those who bear witness sympathize readily with the victim. But when the traumatic events are oWhen the events are natural disasters or “acts of God,” those who bear witness sympathize readily with the victim. But when the traumatic events are of human design, those who bear witness are caught in the conflict between victim and perpetrator. It is morally impossible to remain neutral in this conflict. The bystander is forced to take sides. (pp. 14-15)Unfortunately, people tend to want a world that makes sense and is fair (a Just World) and, further, align with power (e.g., parents, men, authority figures). As a result, bystanders often have a difficult time believing trauma victims, especially those experiencing interpersonal trauma. Imagine being accused of causing your own abuse. Imagine people blaming and shaming you for what you do to survive. Remember, level of social support is one of the strongest predictors of a range of positive outcomes. As she wrote, "Traumatic events destroy the sustaining bonds between individual and community" (p. 307). Herman reminds readers that trauma is not an equal opportunity destroyer. People who had early adversity (including early trauma), were less well-educated, have family members with drug and alcohol problem or in prison, and have fewer social supports post-trauma were more likely to develop chronic PTSD.Despite being first published in 1992, Judith Herman's Trauma and Recovery does bit feel dated; she outlined the dominant narrative that continues to control conversations on trauma. She continues to be referenced regularly, with people filling in the details rather than drawing a whole new picture. Most treatment still emphasizes the roles of the therapeutic relationship and traditional talk therapy. People continue to aver that effective treatment follows three stages (Safety, Remembrance, Reconnection) – although therapists do not invariably follow this process.My edition of Trauma and Recovery has afterwords from 2015 and 2022. Herman's updates remind us of what changes there've been in the 30 years since her first publication: changes in placement of PTSD in the DSM-5 and an addition of complex posttraumatic stress disorder to the ICD; a focus on the role of Adverse Childhood Experiences in poor physical and mental health outcomes; the role of attachments with early caregivers in preventing/reducing trauma; early intervention programs to improve outcomes; and more. Trauma and treatment of trauma continue to be a source of productive writing and research, but as much as anything, we need to focus on advocacy. You and I have the ability to make the world a safer place for children, women, members of the military, and other trauma survivors....more

He was still very young, there were excuses to be found for him. Brother Cadfael had more sense, and no such scruples. The manifold gifts of God are there to be delighted in, to fall short of joy would be ingratitude. (p. 14). So, Cadfael. Cadfael sensitively observes the crime scene, the players, and their world, then rights this world; nonetheless, he shares the stage well. review: You thought you were doing a good job in combatting racism and behaving in antiracist ways? Read Robin DiAngelo's Nice Racism, and you will likely reeYou thought you were doing a good job in combatting racism and behaving in antiracist ways? Read Robin DiAngelo's Nice Racism, and you will likely reevaluate where you are. DiAngelo is the author of White Fragility. There she talked about the ways that white people's emotions get in the way of useful discussions of race with BIPOC people. Here she turns her incisive gaze to those of us who want to believe that we are The Choir, while believing everyone else is a racist. DiAngelo identifies the harmful behaviors that well-meaning, nice, white progressives engage in when talking about race: outwoking each other, credentialing, downplaying their history of privilege, pointing to their own histories of trauma, lecturing BIPOC people about how to "solve" racism (in three easy steps, don't you know?), taking up space, not recognizing power dynamics (especially their own power), hiding behind niceness, and rushing to prove they aren't racist. Nice Racism raises a series of conversations, many of which are not comfortable (they shouldn't be). Still, reading Nice Racism helped me handle several very difficult conversations over the last week somewhat better than I think I might have without it; instead, I listened, worked through my initial defensiveness, and avoided denying responsibility (back to listening). More difficult than it looks on a piece of paper. I expect that I will return to this book regularly when I'm feeling stuck.DiAngelo breaks these conversations down into concrete and clear issues to consider; nonetheless, Nice Racism is not the first book you should read if you want to address racism in your own life. You will need to be open to what she has to say. This is a journey, a rewarding one (for me), but an often uncomfortable one....more

He repeatedly described the bullying and microaggressions that came from being a member of his family, a child celebrity, and an actor who wanted to continue his work – and the stalking, hiding, and gossip that comes from being a celebrity (Juno and Umbrella Academy are the works I know best).Life is difficult, even for people with significant privilege. Page admittedly had significant privilege; yet, was seen and disparaged for these aspects of his life, often in ways that went under the radar, that were often a form of gaslighting: "I think I’m gay."... "No you’re not" (p. 80). Pretending, living a double life, is also a problem. As Kurt Vonnegut said, "We are what we pretend to be, so we must be careful about what we pretend to be." In acting, Page often had to be a different person, yet pretending who he was at his essence undermined him at his core. He often restricted his food intake, self-injured, engaged in more minor numbing and dissociation, and was suicidal."Imagine the most uncomfortable, mortifying thing you could wear. You squirm in your skin. It’s tight, you want to peel it from your body, tear it off, but you can’t. Day in and day out. And if people are to learn what is underneath, who you are without that pain, the shame would come flooding out, too much to hold. The voice was right, you deserve the humiliation. You are an abomination. You are too emotional. You’re not real." (p. 195)Will all of this change now that Page has transitioned? I hope so. Longitudinal research on gender transitioning is promising. It is clear that people often experience self-loathing and gender dysphoria pre-transition. For me, Jane's death was one of the worst things in my life – I spent at least my first year of college depressed – and, paradoxically, one of the most important and transformative events. As a result of her death, I learned life is unpredictable and can be short, that one never knows when a person will leave, and that there is a possibility for great joy as well as great pain. And yet, as Viktor Frankl asserted, life is marked, if not defined by suffering and our response to it.Jane and I had gone to an all-weekend outdoor concert several days earlier, but I hadn't seen or talked to her between the concert and her death, not even to tell her that I had gotten my driver's license. (This was before cell phones and easy access to cars.) For a long time, I felt guilty about not having seen or talked to her. "I believed I had somehow allowed all this to happen" (p. 124). What I am saying is that Hua Hsu's Stay True, a story of friendship, books, writing, and grief, was different from my experience (his friend was murdered, for example), but also similar. Death often comes with all sorts of other emotions – and that person can hang around for years, in both positive and negative ways.Hsu wrote, "This is a book about being a good friend, a term that only occasionally applies to me" (p. 195). While this may be true, he did a fine job describing friendship. One can be good friends even if nothing alike. That push and pull in a relationship can be exciting. As he noted in a letter to Ken following his death, "'I don’t care if you can see through me,' I wrote, confessing to a list of imperfections and insecurities. 'Just as long as you can see me'" (p. 165). Often books written by men feel stiff and only deal with some parts of the emotion spectrum (e.g., anger, resentment, frustration). I liked reading and "watching" the central relationship here, as well as Hsu's relationship with his father, who was often living and working in Taiwan. review: I love a good epic, one where characters are not entrapped by a single storyline, but allowed to grow, change, and show multiple sides of themselves. I love a good epic, one where characters are not entrapped by a single storyline, but allowed to grow, change, and show multiple sides of themselves. Where people live but also die, as we all must eventually do. Where the story is not linear in time, but intertwines several stories (here: war, art, and coming of age). Each of the major characters is a square peg in a round hole world, but deserves a world that lets them be who they truly are.Whalebone Theatre takes place over a 55+ year period (1890 to sometime well after 1945), although is largely set during WW2 (1939-1945). It largely takes place in Dorset (the author's home), which feeds some of the magical aspects of the story, but also plays an important role in the war, being the part of England closest to France. [image]Durdle Door, DorsetCristabel, the Veg (later Flossie), and Digby Seagrave, siblings, but not quite, are the center of Whalebone Theatre. I would say that they were raised by aristocratic wolves, but wolves would rightly feel slandered. Their parents are wealthy dilettantes, who drink and collect artists and sexual partners. Cristabel is a headstrong girl interested in her world – including the whale that washed up on their beach – and stories. Under her tutelage, they – and the adults they roped in – began performing the Illiad and Shakespeare.One GR er commented, "I've never taken to the idea that books can be too white, too middle-class and too, well, sort of First World Problem-y." You can hear the "but…" Many of the adults were each of these "toos." Their mother was typecast as Helen of Troy: "But you must show through your face that you know the man you love is a dilettante. A man who chose beauty over wisdom" (p. 161). She was later painted holding realistic roses but "there is only the outline of her body and a swirly blur where her face should be" (p. 199). The children (later young adults) rarely complained and were intensely loyal, hardworking, curious, and willing to do the right thing, despite the high risks incurred by what they were doing (undercover agents working with the French Resistance).I've read many WW2 books. Although the Seagraves were privileged and protected from some of the worst of the war, Joanna Quinn let them be three-dimensional: to take risks, make mistakes, to love and grow, not only starve in the cold and the dark. This was a thrilling story – and not just the spy parts. I want to grow up to be Cristabel – but would be quite happy to be Digby or Flossie....more

They are often literally there as San worked in a flower shop for much of this short novel, but they also serve as metaphors: shrinking violets, Venus flytraps, surprising papaya palms. Kyung-Sook Shin clarified this double meaning when, for example, San looked up "violets" in her Korean/English dictionary and began reading the definitions surrounding it: Violator: Noun, one who breaks rules, invades, insults, rapes Violence: Noun, a disturbance, disruption, destruction Violet: Noun, a plant, a swallow flower … purple, the color, also used to describe … an oversensitive person, a shy person (“shrinking violet”) Violin: Noun, a musical instrument … a player of, a violinistSan is this shrinking violet, small and lost, surrounded by violence and violators – abandonments, rejections, repressed desire, fire, obsessions, kidnapping, and sexual assault – and also beauty, but the violence overpowered the beauty and later she only saw the violence: "violets, violence, violator." Her memory was incomplete and even radically distorted by earlier experiences. And, this distorted memory impacted her choices: turning away from the kind and toward those who "look like they want to eat her." These distortions blinded her to the choices she had. Violets was written in short, declarative sentences by an omniscient, yet distant narrator. Kyung-Sook Shin began:A little girl.One day in July, rain pours from the skies. In a house with shut doors, a mother closes her eyes as the baby's grandmother offers her the newborn. The mother knows what will happen now. An uncelebrated girl. The infant accepts her mother's closed eyes in lieu of a loving caress, perhaps having intuited her fate from the womb, and does not bother crying.This narrative choice was fitting for a protagonist who barely had a voice, who was dissociated from her feelings, and often was an object acted upon but rarely able to fight back successfully. In her afterward, Shin noted "there are women all around us who exist in silence, anonymous and without anything special about them; she could be me and she could be you." Shin wanted "to amplify the voices of those women, whom no one could hear unless one were listening very carefully, to let them speak through my words."Shin amplified their voices successfully – and disturbs us. review: Fires in the Dark: Healing the Unquiet Mind is at least the third of Kay Redfield Jamison's books that I've read; her memoir, An Unquiet Mind, and NigFires in the Dark: Healing the Unquiet Mind is at least the third of Kay Redfield Jamison's books that I've read; her memoir, An Unquiet Mind, and Night Falls Fast were the other two, although neither since I've been on GR.Jamison's previous books have largely focused on the experience and consequences, good and ill, of bipolar disorder and suicide. Fires in the Dark is largely, "a love song to psychotherapy," a phrase that she would have used to subtitle this book (Schwartz, 2023).Her description of psychotherapy is like that of a courageous journey with a fearless guide. Jamison – and the healers she quoted – describe this journey as often difficult and sometimes paradoxical: "to treat, even to cure, is not always to heal" (p. 3). Strong healers are curious, a refuge, at ease with ambiguity, comfortable with complexity, They help their clients (others prefer to talk about them as "patients") to feel safe, to make "intolerable memories tolerable" (p. 60), and hold "an unshakeable belief in … the ability to get well, compete, and make a difference" (p. 160). To heal is to recognize what was lost and to reshape that loss into something good. It often has a spiritual basis.Jamison referred to a number of healers, most of whom were active in WWI. Almost all were white males, although she quoted some war nurses, as well as some fictional characters (e.g., T. H. White's Merlyn and P. L. Travers' Mary Poppins). She especially focused on the trauma of war. Clearly, early 20th century is where Jamison's reading heart is, but as psychotherapy is a diverse field, focusing her reading there limits the kind of conclusions she could draw about psychotherapy, which she sees as generally long-term and insight-oriented, rather than emphasizing solution-focused treatments, Ericksonian hypnosis, or family therapy treatments.Despite this limitation, Fires in the Dark is an engaging set of musings, although its path is not always clear. You may need to be comfortable with not always knowing where you're going....more

This is something we would have naturally grown out of, like our nondisabled friends, but we live in an inaccessible world, so we have not. We loved our parents but we relished our freedom from them…. The freedom we felt at camp was not just from our parents and our need for their daily assistance in order to live our lives. We were drunk on the freedom of not feeling like a burden, a feeling that was a constant companion in our lives outside of camp. (pp. 24-25)This new way of thinking about the world is one that my colleague needed, but Heumann made clear that so did many of the disability activists: "People had been internalizing the idea that our barriers were our individual problem for so long it was hard to shift. People had to get out of the habit of thinking “I can’t get up the steps because I can’t walk” and get used to thinking “I can’t get up the steps because they’re not accessible.”" (pp. 111-112). As she said, "People with disabilities also have to work to overcome the feeling that asking for an equal opportunity is asking for too much" (p. 153). Radical changes in thinking about the world.Being Heumann would be empowering for anyone with visible or invisible disabilities. It's an exercise in empathy for those of us without a disability. And, if we live long enough, most of us will have some form of disability.Watch Crip Camp on Netflix, which has many of the same people and events that Heumann described....more

review: In 1847, when Tenant of Wildfell Hall was published, it was illegal for women to own property, seek a divorce, or keep children from their father. UntIn 1847, when Tenant of Wildfell Hall was published, it was illegal for women to own property, seek a divorce, or keep children from their father. Until 1870, a married woman in England had no legal existence independent from her husband. Two became one with marriage, although that one was the husband. When the Married Women's Property Act 1870 passed, married women were allowed to be the legal owners of the money they earned and could inherit property.Tenant of Wildfell Hall should be read in this context. Women, their children, and their products were property – sometimes valued property, but property nonetheless.If all was good, life was good. But, in that context, particularly because couples had little knowledge of each other and well-to-do people had little meaningful to do, they experienced a series of related problems: objectification, leading to jealousy, flirtations, affairs, gossip, drug and alcohol abuse, and domestic violence. Mrs. Huntingdon, a strong, thoughtful (and beautiful) woman was doubly oppressed: by society's expectations and laws and by Christianity, which kept her encaged, even after she left her husband. She returned to help her husband after he became ill (maybe Type II diabetes). He was no longer physically abusive, but remained financially and emotionally controlling and abusive.Many men and women in Anne Brontë's novel were scoundrels, although the men were often worse, as they had looser social norms keeping them in place. Charlotte and Emily Brontë's heroes were fixer uppers, tortured souls. Anne Brontë took a clearer feminist perspective on her characters, refusing to glamorize an oppressive man (view spoiler)[although Gilbert Markham got away with jealousy and violence (against other men) (hide spoiler)]. Why do we focus on Jane Eyre and Wuthering Heights instead of Tenant of Wildfell Hall? What does this say about us that we want a rom com (Jane Austen) or brooding Gothic (Charlotte or Emily Brontë) rather than Anne Brontë?After Anne's and Emily's early deaths, a publisher asked Charlotte to prepare new editions of her sisters’ novels, as a tribute to them. Charlotte happily did this for Emily's Wuthering Heights and Anne’s Agnes Grey, but would not do so for Tenant of Wildfell Hall. She told them that Tenant "hardly appears desirable to preserve. The choice of subject in that work is a mistake.”Tenant of Wildfell Hall is subversive, compelling, refreshing and, sadly, continues to be relevant....more

review: We are "too often simply run by losses and hardships long gone by, and by our stockpiled fears." Rather than deal directly with these, we "depart fromWe are "too often simply run by losses and hardships long gone by, and by our stockpiled fears." Rather than deal directly with these, we "depart from ourselves… or …separate one part our awareness from another" (p. 1). We all occasionally disassociate and do so without knowing it – as when we drive down the highway and miss our exit, when we are "unfeeling" after a personal tragedy, when we capably walk and chew gum.Martha Stout capably describes both the normal dissociations and the more problematic types of dissociation. She observed that some people's dissociation, while more florid, may be easier to treat, as they are more willing to take responsibility for their behavior. Others' may not be as apparent, yet more difficult to give up.This book was written in 2001, which is important to note. That was the end of the period where therapists were doing hypnosis with possible trauma victims and discovering Satanic cults and all sorts of other things. Psychotherapy is now more in a middle ground on this issue. We no longer deny child abuse, as had been common into the middle of the 20th century (although there is a lovely article in the New York Times about parental alienation syndrome that indicates that this denial continues). Nor do we say that abuse is everywhere. Now we recognize that horrific abuse occurs and also that we can implant false memories with hypnosis. Each time that Stout talked about her use of hypnosis, I cringed, even as she seemed to otherwise be careful and ethical in her work.Myth of Sanity is very readable and clear, but as one GR er observed, is also is a bit too "twee." review: I haven't read anything by Rebecca Makkai before, but I Have Some Questions for You sold me. I Have Some Questions for You is a complicated mystery exI haven't read anything by Rebecca Makkai before, but I Have Some Questions for You sold me. I Have Some Questions for You is a complicated mystery examining the murder of the narrator's boarding school roommate – rich, beautiful, white – and a search for answers, especially regarding apparently falsely accused athletic trainer at her school. A successful podcaster, her students at her alma mater, and social media obsess on the murder (remember: rich, beautiful, white girl) and its probable miscarriage of justice (somewhat immature Black man, outside the boarding school's power hierarchy). The last book I ed flattened its story: a simple and straight line from birth through adulthood. In I Have Some Questions for You, its narrator is a smart, successful, insightful, and messy hypocrite who drank too much. Her memories of herself as a broken outsider were repeatedly challenged (who of us did not feel like an outsider?); in fact, she often reinterpreted events 20 years earlier. She tried out and rejected eight possible murderers – including herself – and asked many questions of herself, our culture, and the man to whom she was writing.Makkai suggested we are all messy hypocrites – and likely less insightful than Bodie (probably no accident that her name looks like body???). When accusations of sexual abuse were raised against her ex, Bodie refused to see the two cases as similar (her ex's accuser was four years older than the murdered girl). One had agency, the other was just a teen. When do we obtain agency and control? Or was the accuser looking for success and fame in all of the wrong places? Who was the hypocrite? Who the schemer?Makkai wove several stories together into a cohesive whole – the murder; emotional, sexual, and physical violence against women; #metoo; cancel culture; sexual violence in the news; Bodie's podcasts and book; policing and imprisonment of Blacks; and garden variety relationship problems – arguing that these couldn't be understood in isolation. Anonymized lists of violence against women recur repeatedly. Violence surrounds us – and we accept it.It was the one where the woman who stabbed her rapist with scissors was the one who ended up in jail. It was the one where the star had a secret button to lock the doors…. It was the one where the harasser ended up on the Supreme Court. It was the one where the rapist ended up on the Supreme Court. It was the one where the woman, shaking, testified all day on live TV and nothing happened. (p. 62). Makkai did not flatten these stories; she was outraged. She described the casual ways that apparently good guys (growing up to be human rights lawyers) tolerate, support, and even laugh at terrible behavior. She observed that the murderer's actions took place in a system that put the murdered girl at risk and covered up for him. Men and women accepted bad male behavior – due to power differentials, the desire for acceptance or money, loyalty, or a lack of insight and awareness.(view spoiler)[ The good news? While the murderer may have gotten away with it, one of the others likely paid the price for his crimes: "And maybe you’re the missing piece of the puzzle. You, Robbie’s motivation. You, who knew a lot about a lot of things and never said them. You, with a front-row seat to what went wrong. You, a big part of what went wrong" (p. 430). (hide spoiler)]How should we raise young girls? “"It feels wrong to give [little girls] all this happiness and confidence when we know what’s coming. Seventh grade’s gonna hit like a wall. It feels like fattening a pig for slaughter.” // But what was the alternative? Starving the pig?" (p. 404). There are plenty of bad men here (and girls and women), but I Have Some Questions for You is also peopled by men and women who are ethical, work hard, search for justice, and change their minds. Some characters leave you feeling dirty, but others make you proud to walk the same Earth. Many feel like real people and left me caring deeply for them. They left me hopeful about the future. “The victory we’ve achieved is that Omar knows there are so many people who believe him. He told me that’s what he’s thankful for: the growing number of people who understand his innocence, who will continue to fight for his freedom. He’s ready for the battle ahead. You have to remember that he’s an athlete; he knows about endurance.” (p. 433)...more

review: Grace Cho's Tastes Like War mother was diagnosed with schizophrenia, first having noticeable symptoms when Cho was a teenager: “She thinks that peopleGrace Cho's Tastes Like War mother was diagnosed with schizophrenia, first having noticeable symptoms when Cho was a teenager: “She thinks that people are following her, and that Ronald Reagan has our phones tapped. She thinks that one of my friends is involved in a government conspiracy. She watches Wheel of Fortune and thinks that the puzzles are sending her secret messages” (p. 146). She also had periods of food avoidance and anorexia, as well as agoraphobia.If all Cho did, however, was describe what it was like to live with someone with this diagnosis, it would make Tastes Like War one of many similar books. As she said in the introduction for Part III, "Schizophrenia is the story of way that poverty, violence, and being on the wrong side of power drive us mad" (Marrow & Luhrmann, 2016). Cho detailed how systems of oppression, including US imperialism in Korea, contributed to her mother's symptoms and disease. Cho's story was not just about her mother; in fact, she often made inferences about her mother's early life given what she knew about Korea's history and the Korean women who immigrated here, as her mother rarely talked about her life in Korea. Cho captured the gendered racism against Korean girls and women there and abroad and described her mother's and her own experiences of racism and sexism growing up in a predominantly white town in the state of Washington. She outlined how sociocultural factors influence our individual psyches. Although Cho described her mother's schizophrenia and agoraphobia, she also spent almost the first half of Tastes Like War describing her mother's strengths: her hard work, her skills in identifying mushrooms and providing for her family, her love, and her hope that her daughter will have a better life than she had. Although she had difficulty seeing them when she was a teenager – relatively few teenagers see their parents' strengths – she still saw glimpses of them as an adult.Cho turned to her academic work and her baking and cooking to make sense of her mother’s life and to grieve her mother's loss, to help her mother remember and talk about her childhood. Food always has meaning: nurturance, wealth, security, comfort. For Cho's mother, cheeseburgers, one of her favorite American foods, "was a complex symbol of survival and subordination, a luxury item that the Americans could afford to throw away while Koreans starved. For my mother, it also symbolized all the hope and possibility that America had to offer" (p. 274). * * *I have always wondered about how family and friends feel about a memoirist's work. I suspect that most never read these memoirs for any of a number of reasons. In this case, Cho's brother wrote an angry screed arguing that he believed Tastes Like War should be considered fiction (his family seemed to pick up on single words rather than the overall gestalt). Different people in the same family – my own, for example – can have different experiences of that family. In fact, their fight about the nature of the facts and apparent shame about the events described seems to mirror our avoidance of the possible involvement of societal traumas in the etiology of schizophrenia.In a response to her brother's GR , Cho's partner wrote, "Grace has set out to honor her mother’s memory through her work. Her family’s actions do the opposite." Putting a parent's behavior into a broader context would be one very effective way of honoring them: You're not crazy, you make sense. I choose to work to understand you.Regardless, it seems likely that Cho's mother would never have wanted this in-fighting, either in public or in private....more

review: What My Bones Know, written with Stephanie Foo's reporter's eye, is like Around the World in 80 Days, as Foo describes her childhood then her often roWhat My Bones Know, written with Stephanie Foo's reporter's eye, is like Around the World in 80 Days, as Foo describes her childhood then her often rocky search for healing. Her parents were physically and emotionally abusive (think golf clubs, fists, and chopsticks, not prime parenting material); she was a panicked then out of control parentified child. Ultimately, she was abandoned by both parents (her father sent her grocery money, and she continued to live alone in her childhood home). Other ers describe her childhood as "harrowing," which is quite fair, although I didn't find the reading difficult (but this is me).Foo clearly described the consequences of abuse and abandonment: somewhat paranoid interpretations of others' behavior, frequent mistrust, easily triggered anger and stress, expectations of abandonment. Connect the dots, and these are easily related to childhood dynamics.Foo then reported her tempestuous journey in search of healing: EMDR, mindfulness, internal family systems therapy, various coping strategies. A number of these treatments were somewhat helpful for her, but she often dealt with therapists and physicians who made me uncomfortable. (Really, there are some very warm and competent therapists available. If your first is not a good fit, try another.) Foo eventually found the psychologist Jacob Ham, who listened deeply to her and helped her learn to listen to and be there for herself and others as well. Foo included some segments from her therapy in the audiobook; listening to these segments was likely more powerful for me than only reading their transcripts.I also really appreciated Foo's curiosity about Asian immigrants and their histories of trauma both in their first country and this one and how this trauma might have played out for her parents and Asian communities, as a whole. Racial trauma is not just set aside as one moves from one generation to the next, but reinfects members of later generations unless put to rest. Her ultimate description of tiger parents (and frankly abusive ones) was thoughtful, contextualized, and compassionate.People with histories of abuse and neglect are often pathologized and misunderstood. They are often described as unable to heal or fully recover. Foo helps us challenge these simplistic mischaracterizations and expect more of ourselves and others....more

review: Michael Pollan could sell bottled water to people during a flood, sand in the midst of a dust storm. He is an interesting salesperson, as he often shaMichael Pollan could sell bottled water to people during a flood, sand in the midst of a dust storm. He is an interesting salesperson, as he often shares his skepticism but is clearly enthralled by hallucinogens, although wants to use them in the right environment with the right guide. I started reading How to Change Your Mind – and his more recent, This is Your Mind on Plants – as a skeptic. I'd listened to Seasons 1 and 2 of Cover Story on the role of hallucinogens in treating people with trauma and unresponsive depression. Cover Story was clear that there are a number of poorly trained and unethical practitioners out there who have done the sort of work that makes my skin crawl (e.g., numerous boundary violations have been reported).That wasn't Pollan's experience, but he was also picky about who he worked with as guides. As he repeatedly observed, set and setting matter (i.e., how you think about the experience, where and with whom you have it). That set and setting matter to such a degree suggests that any effects are not solely due to the drug, perhaps an interaction of the drug and psychological factors.It is difficult to do good research on the efficacy of hallucinogens – either for the searching well or for the dying, addicted, or depressed. The people serving as participants in such research are probably unusual, not a random sample from the larger population (remember, set and setting?). In addition, one cannot compare hallucinogens to a placebo, even an active placebo, as it is clear that hallucinogens have an effect on the mine, one that both subject, guide, and researcher recognize: one cannot do single, double, triple blinded research.And, I wonder whether this can really become a wonder drug. In the 1950s and 60s, people were paying $500 a session for hallucinogen-assisted therapy. If the cost of hallucinogens came down – and do we really expect that Pfizer and Lilly will get involved, would we want them involved? – much of the cost would still be human labor. Would any insurance panel be willing to pay for a professional mental health worker to accompany a participant for a five-hour session? Would the guides, then, be poorly trained and paid guides (refer back to what I said earlier about the ethics of such work)?And yet, the worried and wealthy well who are looking to expand consciousness may find such experiences tempting and enlightening....more

review: There is no escape from the white man. He has come. When Suffering knocks at your door and you say there is no seat left for him, he tells you not to There is no escape from the white man. He has come. When Suffering knocks at your door and you say there is no seat left for him, he tells you not to worry because he has brought his own stool. The white man is like that. Before any of you here was old enough to tie a cloth between the legs I saw with my own eyes what the white man did to Abame. Then I knew there was no escape. As daylight chases away darkness so will the white man drive away all our customs. (p. 85)Like Things Fall Apart, Arrow of God is about a people in transition, destroyed by an often arrogant culture that often misunderstood members of the Ibo culture, perceiving the Ibo as stupid, lazy, and obstinate. They were often these things and more, just as my own culture often has people with these traits, but they also had people who were wise and forward-thinking. Chinua Achebe fleshed out the Ibo to a greater degree than he did the British, but many mistakes were made on both sides, sometimes due to failures to understand the other. As in Things Fall Apart, Achebe paints a beautiful, often slow portrait of Ibo people and customs. Proverbs add flavor and deepen my understanding of the people and their culture: "To you whatever I say in this house is no more effective than the fart a dog breaks to put out a fire" (p. 9). “Every one of you go back to the house. The inquisitive monkey gets a bullet in the face” (p. 44). I wondered what it would be like to be part of a culture where language, metaphors, and stories are so much a part of the culture. Imagine Ezeulu, instead, telling his wife only that she never listens to him. Captain Winterbottom's language also was often telling: "He would have preferred [a] cold [bath] but must have hot to stay alive (since Africa never spared those who did what they liked instead of what they had to do)" (p. 30). And, while he had some sympathy for the Ibo, it was limited and deeply infected with prejudice:"When you’ve been here as long as Allen was and understood the native a little more you might begin to see things in a slightly different light. If you saw, as I did, a man buried alive up to his neck with a piece of roast yam on his head to attract vultures you know . . . Well, never mind. We British are a curious bunch, doing everything half-heartedly. Look at the French. They are not ashamed to teach their culture to backward races under their charge. Their attitude to the native ruler is clear. They say to him: ‘This land has belonged to you because you have been strong enough to hold it. By the same token it now belongs to us. If you are not satisfied come out and fight us.’ What do we British do? We flounder from one expedient to its opposite.”  (pp. 35-36) This limited view doomed Ezeulu and the Umuaru, as the British assumed that he would jump at the opportunity to serve as a Paramount Chief because he was the Chief Priest of Umuaru and was educating a son in the Christian school. On the other hand, Umuaru's god, Ulu, doomed them by being inflexible. As one of his wives argued, "Ezeulu’s only fault was that he expected everyone—his wives, his kinsmen, his children, his friends and even his enemies—to think and act like himself" (p. 93).I'm reading and enjoying Achebe's African trilogy with my GR friend, IJ....more

review: A Long, Long Time Ago and Essentially True is a surprisingly sweet story – despite the rape, thieving, starvation, deportation, and exploitation charaA Long, Long Time Ago and Essentially True is a surprisingly sweet story – despite the rape, thieving, starvation, deportation, and exploitation characteristic of WW2 novels. Brigid Pasulka did not sugarcoat this time and place, nor did she allow her readers to believe that these characters were victims surviving without hope (although the characters might have characterized themselves that way at some points). Self-confidence, hope, and optimism fluctuated with time and circumstance.[image]Baba Yaga, as in Ivan Yakovlevich Bilibin's, The tale of the three tsar's wonders and of Ivashka, the priest's son (1911)Pasulka's characters were three-dimensional, resilient, and believable: "Irena can squeeze five cups of tea out of a single tea bag, use a match for a week, butter two slices of bread with what others leave on the knife, and wash an entire sink full of dishes with half a liter of hot water" (p. 10). The protagonist is affectionately referred to as Baba Yaga who, in Slavic folklore, is an ogress stealing, cooking, and eating her victims, usually children (imagine Hansel and Gretel's witch on steroids). I like this reclamation of "Baba Yaga." Despite her nickname, she was raised on happy stories: Thanks to Nela’s careful editing, when I arrived in Krakow, my vision of the city was simple and pristine. Nela never talked about the Nazis or the Soviets, never mentioned the food or shoe shortages, the cramped flats, or the curfews. Never the knock in the middle of the night or the screams from the basement of the police station on Rondo Mogilskie (p. 63). Pasulka's dialogue was often acerbic, ironic, and humorous, and always smart: "What is wrong with expressing brotherhood?” “Brotherhood? Why doesn’t anyone ever say sisterhood?" (p. 183). Times and places – rural and mountainous Half-Village, shortly before, during, and after WW2 and Krakow, mostly in the "New Poland" of the early 1990s – were woven together, mostly but not entirely alternating, and illuminating each other. I find myself smiling, just thinking about these people and places, even though their stories took place during very dark times.A Long, Long Time Ago and Essentially True is about the power of telling stories in recovery. It's not South Africa's Truth and Reconciliation Commission, which promoted healing and brought about reconciliation by uncovering the truth about human rights violations. Instead, Pasulka tells stories about both the good and the bad, as that is who we are.I was attracted to and put off by its title and cover art, which reminded me of retellings (okay, I really enjoy retellings) – yet the title and cover caught me long enough to read its blurb and to realize that this wasn't a fairy tale, certainly not an ordinary one....more

review: This is who we are: the richest country on earth, with more poverty than any other advanced democracy. If America’s poor founded a country, that countThis is who we are: the richest country on earth, with more poverty than any other advanced democracy. If America’s poor founded a country, that country would have a bigger population than Australia or Venezuela. Almost one in nine Americans—including one in eight children—live in poverty. (p. 6)Poverty isn't just about the lack of money, but also backbreaking and dangerous jobs, increased violence, less well-funded schools, drugs taken to cope with trauma, and unstable jobs and housing (Desmond is best known for his book Evicted). Sendhil Mullainathan and Eldar Shafir describe “the bandwidth tax” on the poor. “Being poor… reduces a person’s cognitive capacity more than going a full night without sleep.” People preoccupied by poverty and its sequelae “have less mind to give to the rest of life” (pp. 21-22). Even people above the poverty level in the US experience poverty-related problems. Why do so many people in the US live in poverty? Matthew Desmond concludes that people live in poverty because it is convenient for those of us with more wealth and privilege. In order for us to get cheap goods at Walmart (or McDonalds or Burger King or Starbucks), we must pay these workers low salaries – and hope that they access federal services (e.g., EITC and food stamps). Desmond asserts that poverty isn't a line (i.e., the poverty line), but a "knot of social maladies connected to every social problem we care about" (p. 23).Desmond argues that social "ills" that some politicians like to complain about (e.g., single parenting, imprisonment) are not causes of poverty, but consequences of poverty. People don't avoid work, but cannot afford to pay for childcare, for example, while working. Desmond also argues that if some of the "welfare" given to wealthy people (e.g., tax credits on homes, EITC and food stamps benefit businesses by allowing them to pay low wages). When we walk past the homeless, see someone asleep on a bus, he says we should ask, "Who benefits? Not Why don't you find a better job? Or Why don't you move? Or Why don't you stop taking out such bad loans? but Who is feeding off this?" (p. 79). Desmond, of course, also argues that our moral compromises hurt the rest of us. The problem isn't welfare dependence, but welfare avoidance – partly due to confusing paperwork and long lines. If your income puts you above the poverty line, you likely also get more in government benefits than the poor receive. We "prioritize the subsidization of affluence over the alleviation of poverty" (p. 121). If we were really interested in alleviating poverty, we would make different decisions (e.g., fund the IRS, integrate communities across income status).I read Evicted when it came out and loved the data/policy chapters and enjoyed the case examples but thought that book was out of balance. Poverty, by America gets things right from my perspective. Lots of policy and data punctuated by case examples. Did he read my ? :)* * *3/16/2024In the year since I first ed this, I assigned the first chapter to my students, who really liked it. (Several of them grew up in profound poverty.) My mother's book club is reading it this month on my urging. I hope they also like it....more

review: Solito describes Javier Zamora's migration from El Salvador to the United States –"la USA" – at the age of nine, to join his parents in San Rafael. HeSolito describes Javier Zamora's migration from El Salvador to the United States –"la USA" – at the age of nine, to join his parents in San Rafael. He has not seen his mother in four years and does not remember living with his father, who left because of the war.Javier's voice is a moving one and reminded me of Sandra Cisneros' voice in House on Mango Street: clear, open, descriptive. Javier is both smart and observant, the winner of a nation-wide grammar contest, and also young, afraid of being swallowed up by a toilet, unable to tie his shoes.I want what The Baker's family has: everyone in the same room. All my friends and I want to be with our parents, where everything is new, fresh, where garbage is collected by trucks, where water comes out of silver faucets, where it snows the whitest snow, where people have snowball fights and cut real pine trees for Christmas – not spray-paint cotton branches in white like we do here. (p. 5)Zamora clearly described the two month period of his migration: periods of boredom, stuck waiting for the next leg of their travels, punctuated by periods of intense activity and crisis (view spoiler)[(la Migra, a psychotic man on their boat, running into a cactus at night, bees, sprained ankles, dehydration, death) (hide spoiler)]. His authentic voice made Solito more powerful (for me) than a book like American Dirt, which I enjoyed, but which rushed from crisis to crisis in a way that was entertaining but was easily dismissed. As Zamora said in an interview:“It's very easy to ignore an adult, but a little kid that's with his own voice, telling you, describing the world as he sees it … maybe there will be more empathy… immigrants are human. It's very simple. And that hopefully you could see us outside of the headlines, outside of our suffering, that even in the suffering there are joyful moments" (Nicolaou, 2022).In all fairness, though, Zamora has observed that migration is more dangerous now than when he traveled in 1999 – on both the Mexican and US sides. Here, though, four create a family that includes Javier. The kids make up games, the adults tell jokes. Strangers help each other. Can the immigration system in the US become more efficient and more humane? My Irish and German ancestors immigrated to the US recently enough that my maternal grandfather's older sisters were born in Germany, my paternal great-grandparents in Ireland. When politics here get ugly, I fantasize about emigrating. Why don't we offer the same grace and opportunities for people who want to come here for more compelling reasons than my own emigration fantasies?I read Solito as part of the 2023 Read Harder Challenge: a book by a BIPOC author, with a BIPOC narrator, in this case, Zamora, who is engaging and effective in spite of and because of his scratchy voice....more

review: Three people: Katrina, a cis woman; Ames/Amy, a recently detransitioned trans woman, who has impregnated Katrina, but is struggling with being a "fathThree people: Katrina, a cis woman; Ames/Amy, a recently detransitioned trans woman, who has impregnated Katrina, but is struggling with being a "father"; and Reese, a trans woman and Amy's former lover, who they ask to step in to help parent and make it okay for Ames to parent.Torrey Peters identifies Detransition, Baby as domestic bourgeois fiction, a novel that is set in a domestic middle-class environment rather than an exotic one. Such stories are comprised of everyday events and complex emotional situations, a pretext facilitating analysis of the characters’ feelings and passions, which often evolve over the course of the book. (My apologies to those of you who already knew this. I hadn't.) Detransition, Baby shifts across time, so we see Amy's evolution and the events leading to the current dilemma – how they might parent this baby – which is even messier than one might imagine. I am a cis woman with trans friends (one of whom is in the process of trying to become a parent), but I live outside queer culture, so I knew but didn't know many of the dynamics described here, many with significant political overtones. As Peters says, domestic novels are "a place where artistic form and politics could meet up" (p. 341). Peters describes the roles of attractiveness among trans women and cis-passability, reminding me of the privilege I have to pay relatively little attention to my appearance, and conversely the oppression that trans women experience that prevents them from just being themselves. She talked of detransitioning not as a change in gender identity, although it may be, but occurring "because life as a trans person is sometimes incredibly hard, sometimes too hard to bear" (p. 341). And the way that trans women may need to dissociate in their male bodies or during sex. In her dedication, she compared being trans to divorce, "To divorced cis women, who, like me, had to face starting their life over without either reinvesting in the illusions from the past, or growing bitter about the future." But it is Peters' language and thoughtfulness that pulls me in: * "It is not just her clothes that are perfectly pressed: Everything about her is apple crisp and seems newly made. Her skin, Reese imagines, must smell like dryer sheets" (p. 292). * "If I had been born cis, I would never even have had to answer these questions. I wouldn’t have had to prove that I deserve my models of womanhood. But I’m not cis. I’m trans. And so until the day that I am a mother, I’m constantly going to have to prove that I deserve to be one" (p. 176). * From Katrina, "at least from the outside, motherhood is just some vague test designed to ensure that everyone feels inadequate” (p. 174). If you like books that make you see the world from a different perspective, read this. If you like books that are thoughtful and well-written, read this.Read this....more

author: Martin, Clancy
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: How Not to Kill Yourself is a cross between memoir, philosophical analysis, and self-help book by Clancy Martin, a philosophy professor who has been cHow Not to Kill Yourself is a cross between memoir, philosophical analysis, and self-help book by Clancy Martin, a philosophy professor who has been chronically suicidal and struggled with alcoholism, currently struggling less with each compulsion. Martin often talked about "successful" and "failed" suicides, which is a pet peeve of mine. I don't believe there is such a thing as a successful suicide or an inevitable one, and prefer talking about completed suicides. Maybe subtle, but I think we need to change the culture that endorses and often glorifies suicide. Suicide can be contagious, especially depending on how it is discussed in the media and social media (e.g., endorsements, excessive postings, and saintings). Given this contagiousness, I wonder about the readers of the first half of HN2KY. That half establishes his expertise but also presents Martin at his very worst: struggling, seemingly attention-seeking, and often apparently intimate and charming without becoming truly intimate. He acknowledged that one chapter would likely be triggering for people who are suicidal (I suspect more than only people who are suicidal), and that many would be triggering for people who are struggling with alcohol. Family members of people who suicided would likely have significant difficulty with the often self-absorbed, superficial treatment of their concerns – although he seems to truly care about his children and his current wife.Martin's last third, though, was thoughtful and informed about literature written by suicidal and suiciding writers (e.g., Virginia Woolf, David Foster Wallace, Yiyun Li, and Akutagawa), as well as about suicide from a psychological perspective, although he is surprisingly much less interested in what psychology has to say about suicide. As he now identifies as a Buddhist, he framed many anti-suicide interventions from that perspective and focused on what helped him rather than what the literature says (mostly the same things).At almost 500 pages, many of which have Martin figuratively throwing himself down the stairs, I would have liked to have seen HN2KY given an editor who helped him more clearly articulate his vision (and maybe edited out some of Martin's self-promotion and self-congratulation, which are rarely necessary or attractive).My thanks to Penguin who gave me a promotional copy of this book....more

Shouldn't our stories be more realistic, she asked, and point out that life isn't fair? That absurdity is central to the whole of Solutions and Other Problems. Brosh wrote, "If you keep going, you'll eventually realize that the one true answer to all your questions is: Of course it doesn't make sense – what business do you have expecting things to make sense?" title: Things Fall Apart        (The African Trilogy, #1)
author: Achebe, Chinua
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Novels are often about personal transitions, but also sometimes about cultural or societal transitions. Things Fall Apart, the first in Chinua Achebe'Novels are often about personal transitions, but also sometimes about cultural or societal transitions. Things Fall Apart, the first in Chinua Achebe's African trilogy, focused on the latter kind of transition that took place when the traditional Ibo society (now called Igbo) came in contact with white Christians in late 19th century Nigeria. No happy ending here.Things Fall Apart sketched a technologically unsophisticated culture, but Achebe avoided both idealization and caricatures of the Ibo and its people. Okonkwo, its central character, was an unlikable character: uninsightful, inflexible, and afraid of showing positive feelings towards others: "To show affection was a sign of weakness; the only thing worth demonstrating was strength" (p. 28). This style didn't seem to cripple his children, as they had other people who supported them, but his fears and inflexibility crippled him. Interestingly, Obierika, his best friend, reminds us that there is more to Okonkwo, as he himself is a thoughtful and good man who questioned the Ibo way while also accepting it:Why should a man suffer so grievously for an offense he had committed inadvertently? But although he thought for a long time he found no answer. He was merely led into greater complexities. He remembered his wife’s twin children, whom he had thrown away. What crime had they committed? The Earth had decreed that they were an offense on the land and must be destroyed. And if the clan did not exact punishment for an offense against the great goddess, her wrath was loosed on all the land and not just on the offender. As the elders said, if one finger brought oil it soiled the others. (p. 125). Often, a character like Okonkwo would turn me off from a book, but having Obierika and others changed my view of Okonkwo and Things Fall Apart. For me, Okonkwo's tribal family and the Ibo culture was a large, complex, and interesting character, one that engaged.Although the Ibo here are individuals, many of them open to new ideas, Achebe drew whites as rigid and with imperialistic intentions, failing to understand the Ibo. In this respect, Okonkwo was more similar to the white characters than to other Ibo. I have not read the colonialist literature on Africa, which stereotyped Africans, while allowing whites greater agency and superior morality. Agho (2010), for example, criticized Joseph Conrad, Graham Greene, and others, quoting Ogude's critique of Heart of Darkness as “perhaps the most telling account of the rape of Africa by the white man. So complete is the destruction of this portion of the continent that the only Africans represented in the novel are realized as shadows, mere shadows which are often felt merging with the immensity of dark impenetrable, tropical forest” (p. 173).Contrast that with Achebe's own hope for his African novels:Here, then, is an adequate revolution for me to espouse – to help my society regain its belief in itself and put away the complexes of the years of the denigration and self-abasement. And it is essentially a question of education, in the best sense of that word. Here, I think, my aims and the deepest aspirations of my society meet. For no thinking African can escape the pain of the wound in our soul.... I would be quite satisfied if my novels (especially the ones set in the past) did no more than teach my readers that their past – with all its imperfections – was not one long night of savagery from which the first Europeans acting on God’s behalf delivered them. (Achebe, 1965)I both recognize and fail to recognize the propaganda in what I read. I thank Achebe – and Agho and Ogude – for helping me find greater balance.I read Things Fall Apart as part of the 2023 Read Harder Challenge: a book I had DNFed. To be fair, this was a DNF mostly because I got distracted. So many books, too little time....more

review: I didn't like The Nix or The Three-Body Problem, so I was assuming that I didn't like books about gaming (I'm not a gamer). Tomorrow, and TomoI didn't like The Nix or The Three-Body Problem, so I was assuming that I didn't like books about gaming (I'm not a gamer). Tomorrow, and Tomorrow, and Tomorrow is different. Tomorrow, and Tomorrow, and Tomorrow (T3) is about gaming, but often about moral questions. An early game, Solution, placed people in a factory supplying machinery for WW2 Germany; "if you won the game on points, you lost it morally" (p. 32). One of Sadie's classmates at MIT was appalled to have the game identify her as a Nazi.The gaming in T3 challenged my stereotypes about gaming: people die in these games, but rarely shot at each other. Characters were not hyperstylized or -sexualized. Sadie, Mazur, and Marx's games were often thought questions and, although T3 occasionally showed game play, often focused more on the fraught nature of work, friendships, identity, and love. "Maybe she had been like the player in Solution. Maybe she hadn’t asked the right or enough questions because she hadn’t wanted to know the answers" (p. 33). Life, work, and love are complicated and Sam and Sadie often misunderstood each other.[image]Katsushika Hokusai, Under the Wave off KanagawaTheir first commercial game was Ichigo, set against a Hokusai backdrop, where a preverbal child is separated from its parents by a tsunami. Was this choice cultural appropriation – during a time period when people didn't make such choices? They noted they had had many influences: "Dickens, Shakespeare, Homer, the Bible, Philip Glass, Chuck Close, Escher….And what is the alternative to appropriation?" (p. 77). Should we, Mazer asked, only reference our own cultures? And, what is "one's own culture" for a kid raised in New York City and Los Angeles, by a Korean American woman and her Korean immigrant parents? A kid whose absent father was Jewish and who appeared Korean in groups of whites, but white with Koreans.Tomorrow, and Tomorrow, and Tomorrow is a pseudo-documentary told in third person (somewhat reminiscent of Daisy Jones and the Six, omniscient, with occasional observations and interviews from the near future. These comments were so infrequent that I was often taken aback by them, even when I enjoyed the doubled view.My stereotypes of gamers are two-dimensional, but these three people defied simple stereotypes to be complex and changing beings, coming together and moving violently apart due to trauma, challenges, and death; nonetheless, they continued to play and learn from their mistakes. As Marx observed, “What is a game?... It’s tomorrow, and tomorrow, and tomorrow. It’s the possibility of infinite rebirth, infinite redemption. The idea that if you keep playing, you could win.
