review: The Mahdi, a messianic figure in 19th century Sudan, was supposed to signal the end of times and a period of equity and justice. That, unfortunately, The Mahdi, a messianic figure in 19th century Sudan, was supposed to signal the end of times and a period of equity and justice. That, unfortunately, is not how the world works. The resulting war against Turco-Egyptian rule, then later the British, devastated Sudan. Was he the true Mahdi? Although this initially mattered, later his appearance seemed to offer a response to Turco-Egyptian oppression, "injustice unleashes storms; injustice causes the kind of damage that perpetuates itself" (p. 32). But governing people is challenging, as Yaseen observed, "Fanatics can never draw out the good in people. They will go to war I predict. They will raise armies, invade, and pillage because it is only aggression that will keep their cause alive. Fighting an enemy is always easier than governing human complexity" (p. 136). That complexity is at the heart of River Spirit, a story told in eight voices: Musa, Zamzam, Yaseen, Salha, Fatimah, Robert, Charles, Christina. Four female, four male; five from Sudan, three from the UK; one enslaved, five well-educated. The white narrators, in particular, believed they understood others' intentions and acted in what they believed were the best interests of the Sudanese, but their understanding was clouded. General Gordon, for example, sent the Mahdi a gift of a Turkish cloak and a tarbush – when men were killed for wearing a tarbush. The Mahdi sent "the clothes of true humility and asceticism. Clothes like the ones these two are wearing—muslin trousers, a jibbah with patches of different colors and a straw skullcap" (p. 223). General Gordon was outraged – by the Mahdi's words, his tone, his nonchalance. Was the Mahdi's act courage or ploy? From Gordon's perspective, either was a provocation.Robert's paintings of the Sudan were (apparently) beautiful, but he painted two paintings of the conflict. In the former, Gordon was an insignificant figure; the latter rewrote history and played to Britain's patriotic impulses, eventually (according to this narrative) leading to British involvement in the conflict. Christina found her father's painting of Zamzam after his death – naked, savage eyes, muscular, insolent expression – and burned it, as an affront to propriety and his reputation. This painting had probably been his favorite, his masterpiece, from his time in the Sudan.We cannot understand each other. We choose not to understand each other. These misunderstandings lead to violence: Gordon pulled a gun on Robert. Zamzam damaged her portrait, Robert then beat her. The previously described gifts fired outrage and attacks.Nonetheless, at the heart of this story is an unexpected and touching love story, one that withstood class and religious differences, multiple enslavements and separations. Zamzam and Yaseen are both surprising characters, but so was Musa, an uneducated supporter of the Mahdi.[image]Stamp honoring Marie-Guillemine Benoist's Portrait of Madeleine And its cover? The cover might be a depiction of Salha but definitely was not Zamzam, definitely not a woman who heard the river's song. Zamzam was enslaved and poor for most of the book; she had blue-black skin, muscular arms, and tribal scars. Benoist's Portrait of Madeleine is a more likely Zamzam. To be clear, I love this cover – the model's expression, the traditional dress, the swirling "waters" – just not for this book. Would River Spirit have failed to sell if a more accurate depiction was used? Authors generally have some, although limited say over their covers. I hope Leila Aboulela fought long and hard against this one....more

my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: So far, 2023 has been a great reading year; Native Speaker continues this trend. Native Speaker is a heady stew of love, loss, and betrayal; grief, alSo far, 2023 has been a great reading year; Native Speaker continues this trend. Native Speaker is a heady stew of love, loss, and betrayal; grief, alienation, and connection; and perhaps acceptance – all from the perspective of a Korean American man of immigrants who had a complicated relationship to the US. Henry Park is a son, father, husband, and spy, but each of those roles is strained.Who is Henry Park? This is a question that Chang-rae Lee answers several times in different ways. His white wife left a note when leaving him:You are surreptitious B+ student of life first thing hummer of Wagner and Strauss illegal alien emotional alien genre bug Yellow peril: neo-American great in bed overrated poppa’s boy sentimentalist anti-romantic ——analyst (you fill in) stranger follower traitor spy (p. 5)This description would leave me devastated but also slightly pleased that I had been seen (and yet not). His own self-analysis is more nuanced: I am an amiable man. I can be most personable, if not charming, and whatever I possess in this life is more or less the result of a talent I have for making you feel good about yourself when you are with me. In this sense I am not a seducer. I am hardly seen. I won’t speak untruths to you, I won’t pass easy compliments or odious offerings of flattery. I make do with on-hand materials, what I can chip out of you, your natural ore. Then I fuel the fire of your most secret vanity. (p. 8)This makes Park a good friend, an easy date, and an excellent spy. In meeting his wife for the first time, for example, he observed,I did something then that I didn’t know I could do. It was strangely automatic. Instantly I was thinking of the lover she might want, the man whom she’d searched out but hadn’t yet found in her life. I thought of the ways Nils was perhaps falling short. I put myself in her place and imagined her father and mother. Boyfriends, recent loves. (p. 14)How flattering and attractive! But I don't think I would want to be married to a chameleon. The traits desirable in a date are different than those in a spouse and partner.This is a spy novel unlike any I've read (not that I've read many in the last 40 years), although sometimes I thought of John le Carré while reading this. Henry Park, like le Carré's protagonists, is knowledgeable and competent, an outsider, a consummate observer, loyal. These traits/skills make Park a good friend and colleague – and a wonderful spy (view spoiler)[– until he's not, as these strengths both facilitate and undermine the spying enterprise (hide spoiler)]. This story focuses more on Henry as a person, which includes the spy, rather than primarily the task at hand. Love, loyalty, and spying complement (and fail to complement) each other here.Past and present circle and intertwine in Lee's narrative. At times, it may seem that there is no Story, just extended anecdotes, but then life is rarely linear and direct. Read this....more

review: Sanditon is Jane Austen's novel that she had been working on when she got ill, then died. She had written about 10 ½ of the ultimate 30 chapters at thSanditon is Jane Austen's novel that she had been working on when she got ill, then died. She had written about 10 ½ of the ultimate 30 chapters at that point. The version I read was finished in 1975 by "Another Lady," a pseudonymous British novelist identified as Anne Telscombe on Goodreads.Austen's section of the book really only sets the scene, as it is only the first 22% of the book. All but three of the final characters can be found here, but the raw materials could be recombined in dozens of different ways and still remain within Austen's oeuvre. In fact, this version of the finished novel – there are probably others – appears very different from PBS's version (we're early in Season 1). As a result, Sanditon should probably be authored by "Another Lady" with Jane Austen.Is Sanditon consistent with Austen's other works? By my reading, yes. Charlotte, the heroine, is an observant but shy country girl who made some errors in understanding others, some because they were hiding their intent, others because she was self-absorbed with love. The characters vary, but there are a number of narcissists, silly buffoons, hypochondriacs (who made me very thankful for modern medicine), and of course the Love Interest, who is obscure at best. Charlotte noted, "Very few of us lack superficial faults and we must rely on each other’s kindness to overlook them." (p. 97). Many of the characters here have far more central faults. As Austen's other books, there is no place for death, maimings, or politics, but there is a happy ending. Austen (and "Another Lady") wrote what we would call romcoms. Charlotte is a very likeable character, as are all of the Parkers – and several other characters. Unlike many of the others, she underestimated herself; this lack of self-worth (or relative worth?) was a central motivating force for much of the action. Charlotte "well knew that such beauty as she herself possessed was unlikely to tempt so popular, polished and lively a young man, that her fortune was nonexistent and her personality a trifle narrow and over-decorous for his tastes" (p. 242). Any reader of Austen knows that her characters do tempt such men.A fun read....more

There's something to a dystopia painted with a more subtle brush, where good and evil reside in a single person, where people fail to match simple stereotypes and stories (e.g., Sunlight Pilgrims).[image]Norman Rockwell, The Problem We All Live With, 1964Our Missing Hearts is a subtle dystopia. Our Missing Hearts is set maybe 20 years in the future, with numerous events crossing the line from life to novel, so close that I was looking up PACT (Preserving American Culture and Traditions Act) to determine whether it was real. Its characters are believable, and I would want Bird, Margaret, Sadie, Domi as friends, even Ethan (I would want to tell him to grow a pair, although I might make choices similar to his own). Bird's father told him: "Don’t attract attention. Keep your head down. And: If you see any trouble, you go the other way, understand?" (pp. 75-76). Many of us would choose to tell our children to do these things. Many of us already do. [image]George Floyd mural at CUP Foods, where he was murderedOne way the government controlled people under PACT was by removing or threatening to remove children from un-American environments, "the definition of which was ever expanding: Appearing sympathetic to China. This strategy of family separations is not a new one but one used throughout US history (e.g., boarding schools for indigenous children, separations of slave families, migrant families at the US/Mexico border, class inequities in the foster care system). (view spoiler)[Margaret chose an equally valid, although perhaps surprising strategy to keep Bird and other children safe (hide spoiler)] PACT also sounded much like McCarthyism (Joseph, not Kevin). These similarities added to its truthfulness.[image]Keith Haring, Ignorance = Fear / Silence = Death, 1989I loved that art, poetry, and memoir were at the center of political protests in Our Missing Hearts – although art was also used to support the status quo. It's not always friendly to white women either, but white women'sThere are clearly exceptions, but this isn't a world that's friendly to BIPOC women. It's not always friendly to white women either, but white women's emotional needs are frequently prioritized over those of BIPOC women. White women may not "play fair." What is unfair? Clearly false claims of rape against Black men (think Emmett Till) are unfair, but sometimes this unfairness is much more subtle. At a meeting I was at last year, when a white woman felt guilty – she wasn't even being discussed or attacked – she began crying and our discussion of race just stopped. How can you talk about serious things with someone who is sobbing? Instead, we soothed her feelings, leaving the others in the room, especially the black women, out in the cold. The issue here is the fragility with which some people respond when their worldview, their dominance is threatened.[image]Emmett Till (1941-1955)What is unfair? White women believing that we cannot tolerate any racial discord. As Ruby Hamad argues, The mere suggestion that being white has meaning often triggers a range of defensive responses. These include emotions such as anger, fear, and guilt and behaviors such as argumentation, silence, and withdrawal from the stress-inducing situation. These responses work to reinstate white equilibrium as they repel the challenge, return our racial comfort, and maintain our dominance within the racial hierarchy. (p. 12)Hamad felt guilty when a Black woman lost her job for posting an article Hamad had written about white tears. She then noted, "But this reaction is itself internalized racism, scolding people of color for whatever bad thing happens to us, telling us it’s our own fault, keeping us in check by taking away our will to speak" (p. 15).What is unfair? Failing to see beyond stereotypes when looking at BIPOC women: Jezebels, Black velvet, harem girls, China Dolls, Princess Pocahontas. "If [BIPOC women] are angry, it is because we are bullies. If we are crying, it is because we are indulging in the cult of victimhood. If we are poised, it is because we lack emotion. If we are emotional, it is because we are less rational human and more primitive animal" (p. 16). my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Rachel Aviv's Strangers to Ourselves is a provocative set of case studies of people with mental health problems, including Ms. Aviv herself, who was (Rachel Aviv's Strangers to Ourselves is a provocative set of case studies of people with mental health problems, including Ms. Aviv herself, who was (inappropriately?) diagnosed with anorexia nervosa at age 6. Her case studies give a voice to a small but increasingly loud anti-psychiatry current in the mental health field. Few say that medications and diagnoses are not useful, but they can also be a source of bias and discrimination. They can be self-limiting and damaging. How can medications and diagnoses be damaging? We can get caught in self-fulfilling and self-limiting "stories" about illness: What caused problems? Can they be reduced? How? Should a diagnosis be the central, defining life story or a story (e.g., "I am depressed" or "occasionally a person with depression")? Diagnoses and case conceptualizations can change what we see ourselves as capable of doing or being. As a result, Aviv "wanted to emphasize the diversity of experiences of mental illness, the fact that, when questions are examined from different angles, the answers continually change" (p. 25). Aviv's book is roughly organized around six people. Four are relatively privileged: three white women, and a white man, all in the US. The Black woman was poor and spent much of her early life in foster care. The Indian woman came from a privileged background, but India and the colonial mental health system had conflicting views on spiritual goals and appropriate treatments for "problems." Each of Aviv's case studies is three dimensional, using information from diverse informants: family members, friends, and members of the mental health field. They led to a series of questions (some hers, some her readers). Is Naomi a murderer? psychotic? oppressed and misinterpreted by the system? a square peg in a round hole? As Naomi's mother said about her own experience, "Who wouldn’t be depressed when you don’t have enough money to take care of your children?... Oppressed/depressed—either way, you can’t feel good about yourself” (p. 123). Although Aviv does not offer single, clear answers, I suspect that is her point: there aren't easy, simple answers. Recognizing the questions that should be asked can help us communicate understanding and empathy, develop shared goals with our clients, and reduce the probability that clients and the mental health system will choose ineffective stories that create rather than remove problems....more

review: Anybody will tell you the born of this world are marked from the get-out, win or lose. (p. 2). Demon Copperhead is Barbara Kingsolver's brilliant reteAnybody will tell you the born of this world are marked from the get-out, win or lose. (p. 2). Demon Copperhead is Barbara Kingsolver's brilliant retelling of David Copperfield. Demon (what else would you be called if named Damon?) had a hard life from the get-go. His father died before his birth, he was parentified and caring for his mother even as a young child, his stepfather was abusive of both her and him, and his mother eventually overdosed, after having been clean for a long time. From there, Demon entered the foster care system, where he was enslaved, underfed, and maintained in abusive, neglectful, and dirty surroundings, foster parents themselves attempting to make a living in difficult places. Free school lunch and Backpacks of Love programs filled in some of the gaps, but young Demon experienced few adults who had his back until middle school – except for the Peggots, who were often overextended themselves.Demon made mistakes – layers or layers of them – and engaged in considerable self-blame, "What a useless dickhead. Knowing basically from birth that my mom was not to be counted on. And still no plan B" (p. 48), but Kingsolver clearly attributed the opioid crisis, foster care system, and chronic unemployment to systemic factors. Government is pro-Pharma (oxycodone, fentanyl, etc.) because it is pro-business, for example. Tommy Waddles observed government is on the side of the money-earning people, and down on the land people [e.g., Appalachians]…[because] money-earning ones pay taxes. Whereas you can’t collect shit on what people grow and eat on the spot, or the work they swap with their neighbors. That’s like a percent of blood from a turnip. So, the ones in charge started cooking it into everybody’s brains to look down on the land people, saying we are an earlier stage of human, like junior varsity or cavemen. (pp. 522-523)As June Peggot concluded, "The first thing we had to do… was quit thinking this mess was our fault. 'They did this to you'” (pp. 455-456). Demon, despite it all, was resilient. Even when he fell hard, he was able to pull himself back up, that he was "like somebody of worth" (p. 358), but he was an attractive, bright boy with Superpowers, who also had adults who believed in him and supported him, even though he often dismissed their good views of him. How can you not like Demon, even as he circled the drain? He was "a beautiful man with too much heart for the raw deal he got" (p. 455). What about the Swap-Outs of the world, those kids who have three strikes against them from the very beginning, have no Superpower, and no adults believing in them?I read David Copperfield before the Kingsolver, which added a layer of enjoyment (seeing Uriah Heep, for example, become U-Haul Pyle), but reading it was in no way necessary. Like the Dickens book, Kingsolver's is a takedown of systems for responding to child poverty, but it was fresh and vibrant, even though of its plot elements were take offs and reworkings of the Dickens – and to my ear, often better than the Dickens. Demon noted, "a good story doesn’t just copy life, it pushes back on it" (p. 520). I've also read and responded to Kendi's Be Antiracist and Saad's Me and White Supremacy. The Antiracism Workbook is my favorite of the three, perhaps because the writers are psychologists. Their prompts focus on beliefs, emotions, and actions and, like Kendi's book, assumes that both Blacks and whites will have issues to work on, although those issues may take different forms. Their workbook is more palatable to a White woman, as I am, than Saad's often confrontational book. Bryant and Arrington's workbook is the most "embodied" book, encouraging a number of interventions to get out of your head (Kendi tends to encourage thinking over feeling), to stop avoiding and denying, and to feel and act: breathe, sway to music, feel.Although the three books overlapped to some degree, it was useful and thought-provoking to work through all three books in the last 2 ½ years, so I'm not sure that one was right for me and another wrong, I just read each at a different point in my journey and focused on different things....more

review: In most dystopian novels, the characters recognize that their society is less than ideal. In Fahrenheit 451, the peripheral characters believe that thIn most dystopian novels, the characters recognize that their society is less than ideal. In Fahrenheit 451, the peripheral characters believe that they live in the best of times. They can drive 100+ mph in their beetles and forget everything. Their "family" talks to them all day from the parlor walls – and they can talk back if they've bought the media upgrade. But… they were unaware and did not have intimate relationships with others, and reflection and self-reflection were discouraged:“Do you know why books such as this are so important? Because they have quality. And what does the word quality mean? To me it means texture. This book has pores. It has features. This book can go under the microscope. You’d find life under the glass, streaming past in infinite profusion. The more pores, the more truthfully recorded details of life per square inch you can get on a sheet of paper, the more ‘literary’ you are. That’s my definition anyway. Telling detail. Fresh detail. The good writers touch life often.... So now you see why books are hated and feared? They show the pores in the face of life.” (p. 79)Books were one way of seeing the "pores" but, frankly, there are many ways of stopping to smell the roses, to see the world. In burning books, their society also encouraged an avoidance of anything real. Montag, a fireman, described book burning:"The police went first and adhesive-taped the victim’s mouth and bandaged him off into their glittering beetle cars, so when you arrived you found an empty house. You weren’t hurting anyone, you were hurting only things! And since things really couldn’t be hurt, since things felt nothing, and things don’t scream or whimper, as this woman might begin to scream and cry out, there was nothing to tease your conscience later. You were simply cleaning up. Janitorial work, essentially." (p. 35)This inversion of what was real was also seen in how behaviors were labeled. Seventeen-year-old Clarisse who, from our perspective, seemed exactly on track, had been labeled "insane." She said,“I’m antisocial, they say. I don’t mix. It’s so strange. I’m very social indeed. It all depends on what you mean by social, doesn’t it? Social to me means talking to you about things like this…. Or talking about how strange the world is. Being with people is nice. But I don’t think it’s social to get a bunch of people together and then not let them talk, do you? An hour of TV class, an hour of basketball or baseball or running, another hour of transcription history or painting pictures, and more sports, but do you know, we never ask questions, or at least most don’t; they just run the answers at you, bing, bing, bing, and us sitting there for four more hours of film-teacher. That’s not social to me at all. It’s a lot of funnels and lot of water poured down the spout and out the bottom, and them telling us it’s wine when it’s not." (p. 27)The society of Fahrenheit 451 could feel dated, as this novel was published in 1953, seventy years ago; yet, it was addressing modern issues: censorship, authoritarian controls, loss of connection, and anti-intellectualism. Fahrenheit 451 has lots of "pores."...more

This is the most-realistic of the three, also one with the lowest mortality.In Lucy By the Sea, Elizabeth Strout sketched the loneliness and confusion of the pandemic, the obsessiveness that many of us had with the news and with numbers, and missing old friends and family, as well as the unexpected gifts that we may have found: the sea's beauty, a more mindful presence, new friends. And, despite COVID crashing through our lives like a bull in a china shop, our lives went on: we connected and lost relationships, marriages ended and relationships began, and distant memories of childhood continued to touch our current lives.Lucy By the Sea is the most recent installment in the Amgash series. I read its first installment in 2016, but haven't (yet) read the middle two books. That was okay. Here, Lucy is a successful novelist and memoirist who came from nothing. Her family was too poor for salt and pepper shakers. They frequently ate molasses on white bread for dinner, for lack of anything more substantial. It was also a family that was emotionally, physically, and probably sexually abusive, one that never said "I love you," (view spoiler)[at least until her brother's death (hide spoiler)]. These contrasts – profound neglect with international travel, the ability to leave New York for Maine when COVID first appeared, and people who loved Lucy enough to save her – were an interesting subtext running throughout the book. She is stuck between her real mother and her "nice made-up mother," feeling alone and lost, but also sometimes recognizing that she is supported and loved. Perhaps Lucy's history – a poor, uneducated, COVID-denying family – made it possible for her to build a friendship with a vaccine-refusing, supporter of the former president and for that friendship to feel real rather than forced, even though Lucy is currently affluent and liberal. She understood people and valued trying to understand them even when they were doing things that didn't initially make sense. She had several "visions" – what I prefer to see as deep empathy – at various points, although also sometimes missed the obvious.Lucy was more anxious and neurotic than I'd prefer (although my friends are often anxious and neurotic), but I felt like I was walking with her along the beach, sharing a conversation with her. The first person narrative contributed to this feeling, but so did her deep honesty and empathy. I was sad to say good-bye to Lucy, even though I anticipate another installment (and look forward to the two I skipped)....more

review: Poor Oliver! He rivals Pauline (from The Perils of Pauline) and may have been her precursor, as he was repeatedly snatched from safety and dragged intPoor Oliver! He rivals Pauline (from The Perils of Pauline) and may have been her precursor, as he was repeatedly snatched from safety and dragged into the fire. What a wonderful way to serialize a book: Oliver Twist was released in 24 pieces between 1837-1839.Dickens, as in other novels, decried the life allotted the poor. Oliver's mother died in childbirth and other family members were unidentified. As a result, he had few options available, none good (workhouse, crime, death). In fact, the criminals were stereotyped and described in terms of their roles: the Jew, the robber, the murderer, the bastard child. I'm not clear whether this was the time that Dickens was writing or that Dickens was commenting on how crime flattens those engaging in it into stereotypes. At least it can flatten them, as few of the thieves escaped with their lives and moved on to another life. (view spoiler)[Similarly, Rose and Oliver's reputations were saved only through a series of accidents. (hide spoiler)]Another way of reading Oliver Twist is that this is Dickens' study of nature/nurture. Is it the criminals' nature to do bad things or their environments? Can good characters be corrupted? Can they be saved? (view spoiler)[If good-natured and beautiful. (hide spoiler)] I loved Dickens' asides. The system was often described as being for Oliver's benefits – and any reader would clearly see through the self-congratulatory claims:Let it not be supposed by the enemies of “the system,” that, during the period of his solitary incarceration, Oliver was denied the benefit of exercise, the pleasure of society, or the advantages of religious consolation. As for exercise, it was nice cold weather, and he was allowed to perform his ablutions every morning under the pump, in a stone yard, in the presence of Mr. Bumble, who prevented his catching cold, and caused a tingling sensation to pervade his frame, by repeated applications of the cane. As for society, he was carried every other day into the hall where the boys dined, and there sociably flogged as a public warning and example. And so far from being denied the advantages of religious consolation, he was kicked into the same apartment every evening at prayer-time, and there permitted to listen to, and console his mind with, a general supplication of the boys, containing a special clause, therein inserted by authority of the board, in which they entreated to be made good, virtuous, contented, and obedient, and to be guarded from the sins and vices of Oliver Twist: whom the supplication distinctly set forth to be under the exclusive patronage and protection of the powers of wickedness, and an article direct from the manufactory of the very Devil himself. One in 4 women and 1 Nearly 20 people per minute are physically abused by an intimate partner in the US, more than 10 million women and men annually. One in 4 women and 1 in 9 men experience severe domestic violence. On average, more than 20,000 phone calls per day are placed to domestic violence hotlines. Guns in a domestic violence situation increases the risk of homicide by 500% (NCADV Statistics, n.d.).There are multiple causes to domestic violence: economic distress and homelessness, isolation, stereotypic gender roles for both men and women, substance abuse. And, domestic violence can exacerbate poverty, homelessness, educational and employment disparities, and isolation. Domestic violence is not, however, limited to people who are poor and unemployed. No Visible Bruises outlined the problem(s), but also described both cases of domestic violence and the programs inspired by them: danger assessments, teams of detectives focused on high risk programs, abuser intervention programs, coordinated community responses, shelters and their alternatives, and hotlines. Rachel Snyder concluded:If I had to whittle down the changing world of domestic violence to just one idea that made all the difference, it would be communication. Across bureaucracies, certainly, but also political ideologies and programs, people and systems and disciplines. (p. 276)What families and agencies don't know, don't share, can kill. Collaboration among knowing parties helps, but so do small things: diapers and grocery money, laminated rather than paper copies of protection from abuse orders, afternoon rather than early morning court times, visiting the victim's home rather than expecting them to visit the police, taking a step back from an argument. Victims need stable housing and employment, help with childcare, and support. Leaving a relationship is difficult, even when the victim knows that staying may kill them....more

review: “Some stories,” she says, “can be both false and true at the same time.” (p. 317). Cloud Cuckoo Land follows five children and one book across time – “Some stories,” she says, “can be both false and true at the same time.” (p. 317). Cloud Cuckoo Land follows five children and one book across time – and centuries, continents, and space – as worlds fell apart (e.g., war, climate change, disease). Its characters often dealt with personal barriers: homophobia, religious intolerance, being orphaned, autism, and cleft palates. None of us escapes life unscathed. Doerr followed his central characters over the arc of their lives, having noted that a child character allows him “to see more nakedly some of the things that we’ve elided or erased in our minds because of age” (Beckerman, 2021). Even as some characters aged, however, they remained open to new perspectives on lives. Two, even on their last day, acted with courage and integrity, (view spoiler)[one finding "he is Aethon turning his back on immortality, happy to be a fool once more" (p. 617). That would be a nice way to die (hide spoiler)]. Books open doors and Cloud Cuckoo Land, Antonius Diogenes' ancient lost (and fictional) novel was no exception. His Cloud Cuckoo Land described a shepherd, Aethon, who sought a magical, heavenly place in the sky, but first had to experience a series of (physical) transformations. Stories help us make sense of the world, inspire us, and spark our imagination. Decoding this degraded manuscript and reading it aloud sustained these characters, gave them courage, and offered them hope and meaning, often in the most dire of circumstances. Reading the ancient Cloud Cuckoo Land aloud relieved one character's pain as she approached death, healed a sick child, and even lured birds to feed them as they starved.Diogenes' Cloud Cuckoo Land tells of Aethon's search for a utopia, but Doerr's Cloud Cuckoo Land questioned whether that utopia could be achievable or was even desirable."I have heard of a city in the clouds where thrushes fly into your mouth fully cooked and wine runs in channels in the streets and warm breezes always blow. As soon as I become a brave eagle or a bright strong owl, it is there I intend to fly.” “You always think the barley is more plentiful in another man’s field, but it’s no better out there, Aethon, I promise you,” said the crone. “Bandits wait around every corner to bash your skull and ghouls lurk in the shadows, hoping to drink your blood. Here you have cheese, wine, your friends, and your flock. What you already have is better than what you so desperately seek.” (p. 69).But, although Cloud Cuckoo Land is a cautionary tale about utopias, his characters are not complacent. They – like Doerr himself (see Doerr's 2017 op ed) – see the horrors in their world and attempt to do something about the problems they face (not always successfully).Cloud Cuckoo Land is full of "Easter eggs," which means that although you and I may read the same text, we may see different things now – and the next time we read it. It is a long book (600+ pages), so it makes many side trips: lovely descriptions of reading and translation, even by young children; anger about our destruction of the Earth; people trapped by prejudice, sometimes escaping those traps; frustrations with intimacy – and surprising connections; recognitions that even the all-knowing know nothing. "He that knows all that Learning ever writ, knows only this—that he knows nothing yet” (p. 445)....more

review: In the second volume of Maus, Art Spiegelman continued his father's story, beginning with his stay in Auschwitz (what he called Mauschwitz), with manyIn the second volume of Maus, Art Spiegelman continued his father's story, beginning with his stay in Auschwitz (what he called Mauschwitz), with many of the same themes as in the first volume, although his father noted, "and here my troubles began." [image]Art's father, Vladek, was a survivor. He worked hard in Auschwitz, learned desirable skills (tin smithing, shoe repair, etc.), curried favor and alliances people in power – and those without. He was helped by others when it was to their advantage, but also by people, Poles and Germans included, for whom there was no advantage. Nonetheless, "in some ways [Vladek] didn't survive" (p. 90). How can your view of the world remain untainted after seeing Auschwitz, Birkenau, and Breslau? Vladek became miserly, a difficult and complaining racist who alienated his family – and burned his beloved wife's diaries of the war rather than having to think about such a period. His son and daughter-in-law felt sorry for Vladek – as does the reader – until any of us had to spend any time with him. Vladek's behaviors are likely survivor's guilt, preparations for future disasters. What he did to survive, however, hurt him in the long run.[image]Maus II was more autobiographical of the artist than the first volume, which was more focused on Vladek. This volume considered the difficulties of writing/drawing about the Holocaust – "sometimes I just don't feel like a functioning adult" (p. 43). When Art talked with his "shrink," he himself shrunk physically (in the drawings), as he had difficulties facing his arguments with his father, thoughts of Auschwitz, etc. We saw his struggles in how to draw his wife, Françoise, and present Vladek's complaints and tics. He reflected on his older brother, who died in a concentration camp. Richieu could remain an ideal child, never throwing tantrums, while Art was "a pain in the ass," as any flesh and blood child must be.One advantage of a graphic novel is that it can include more layers of life in and around the Holocaust than many Holocaust novels are able to do. The first drawing in this , for example, both flattened the Jews and made them all alike, but each mouse was also an unique individual. Art can shrink when talking to his therapist, without spending words on that shrinkage. The reader can see the ways that Vladek is difficult – returning, for example, a partially eaten box of cereal because his estranged second wife bought it – and identify with Art and Françoise, but also make those decisions for ourselves.Drawings are from this volume....more

review: Better terrible truths than kind lies.Crooked Kingdom is a high action/adventure sequel – grand plans go awry, but there are always several layers of Better terrible truths than kind lies.Crooked Kingdom is a high action/adventure sequel – grand plans go awry, but there are always several layers of back-ups – and a grand coming-of-age story. Most people will focus on the former, so I'll take the road less traveled.In Crooked Kingdom, this group of homeless, parent-less teens living on the streets are each damaged in one way or another. Several hide their gifts – and struggle as a result. Most are traumatized and rejected by parents; they have been trafficked, abused, and are outsiders. But, they are not like Alys, who is told kind lies, and remains silly and unaware.Fear is a constant companion, but a companion that kills rather than saves.How do you handle relational trauma without having it damage other relationships? Most people don't even ask themselves this question initially. Others handle the violence of their divided, prejudiced world by closing their eyes. This is only a partial solution: "You’re the man who sits idly by, congratulating yourself on your decency, while the monster eats his fill. At least a monster has teeth and a spine” (p. 62). In Crooked Kingdom, this motley crew lives with integrity and self-acceptance, helping each other recognize "you could love something and still see its flaws" (p. 383). Are my weaknesses all of me or only part? “You’re not weak because you can’t read. You’re weak because you’re afraid of people seeing your weakness. You’re letting shame decide who you are" (p. 283). They begin to declare their power instead of hiding it. “What kind of mother would I be to my son if I hid away my talents? If I let fear be my guide in this life? You knew what I was when you asked that I choose you, Colm. Do not now suggest that I be anything less” (p. 258).They support each other and – the good parents among them – their children, even when they disagree with their decisions: “You’re my son, Jesper. I can’t protect you. Maybe I shouldn’t have tried. But I will be there even when you falter. Every time” (p. 513).These messages are powerful, especially for young adults, who tend to think dichotomously, who believe that they are what was done to them. This crazy roller coaster of a story is great fun, but what makes this an especially good story is that the characters believe in and heal each other – and without a dose of saccharine. “I would come for you,” he said, and when he saw the wary look she shot him, he said it again. “I would come for you. review: What is real? Are we real? Do you perceive the same world that I do? I asked some of these questions as a teenager (and, to some degree, now).[image]TWhat is real? Are we real? Do you perceive the same world that I do? I asked some of these questions as a teenager (and, to some degree, now).[image]The young woman or witch?These questions underlie Emily St. John Mandel's Sea of Tranquility, a book that is, in theory, a stand-alone book, but that has characters that first showed up in The Glass Hotel and a character who wrote a famous book about a pandemic (much like St. John Mandel's Station Eleven), right before a pandemic. Its central characters move around through time (20th through 25th centuries), attempting to identify and resolve a glitch in the timeline, a glitch that confused me in The Glass Hotel and here had much larger implications, as it suggested that our world was a corrupted computer file: "If we can run fairly convincing simulations of reality now, think of what those simulations will be like in a century or two. The idea with the simulation hypothesis is, we can’t rule out the possibility that all of reality is a simulation” (p. 99). When asked why she wrote sci fi in her last book, Olive Llewellyn said much as St. John Mandel might have, "but there’s just, there is so much death. There’s death all around us. I don’t want to write about anything real” (p. 168). Those of us who followed the death counts in the last several years or who had a family member die of COVID could easily empathize. Nonetheless, Sea of Tranquility reads more like literary fiction than science fiction, with very little focus on science or space travel, even though the book's characters can travel across time and galaxies. These things are incidental to the real questions of the multiverse: "rats can’t talk here, she pointed out, but does it logically follow that they can’t talk anywhere?" (p. 69).Space travel is also incidental to her discussions of living through a pandemic. Llewellyn was on a book tour, discussing her pandemic book shortly before the start of the pandemic and stayed on tour, with the hubris that we humans often have, rather than recognizing that she could die any day. Any of us could die any day.Pandemics don’t approach like wars, with the distant thud of artillery growing louder every day and flashes of bombs on the horizon. They arrive in retrospect, essentially. It’s disorienting. The pandemic is far away and then it’s all around you, with seemingly no intermediate step. (p. 107)I loved Station Eleven, but wasn't thrilled by The Glass Hotel. I started Sea of Tranquility and wasn't thrilled, feeling distant from several of its drifting, alienated characters. Ultimately, Sea of Tranquility was quietly moving, as its characters groped with life – real or otherwise – and lived with dignity, purpose, and connection. review: Historical fiction, Horse takes place in three periods of US history, 1850-1875, 1950s, and 2019, centered around at least six major characters in a cHistorical fiction, Horse takes place in three periods of US history, 1850-1875, 1950s, and 2019, centered around at least six major characters in a complicated story about horsing, slavery, art, and the scientific process. As a story about these things, Horse works well. But it's not just about any horse, but arguably the fastest Horse in the 19th century and, in this book, that Horse becomes a stand-in for several other issues. Its focus on objectification and empathic subjectivity is fascinating: Horses, slaves, and Black men blossom from native talent and drive, but when they are treated as things, they are damaged – or give up. And, those in power repeatedly strike out to keep others in control, often with bad result: "He came to believe that horses lived with a world of fear, and when you grasped that, you had a clear idea how to be with them" (pp. 13-14). Why do we do that???But objectification works both ways. In numerous places, people act with ill intent – stealing from and beating slaves, putting their ownership before the slave's name (e.g., Alexander's Jarrett), and even failing to recognize them – but there are other places where microaggressions are more subtle. Jess, for example, assumed that Theo was stealing her bike – which was both an unusual, high-end bike and identical to her own. Theo responded with anger at being stereotyped, Jess with guilt about her cluelessness. In discussions about art, Theo, an art history graduate student, noted that some 19th century representations of Blacks were ridiculous. His initial thesis was "that these paintings were never meant to be viewed as portraits of individuals, merely status signifiers of the privilege, wealth, and power of the White sitters" (pp. 56-57). Frederick Douglass "mocked the caricatures that White painters produced—the broad noses, the thick lips—and asked his readers to consider if they’d ever seen, in life, an actual face that combined all these exaggerated features" (p. 57). As a different sort of example, the Black woman in Manet's Olympia was almost invisible.[image]Manet's Olympia (1863)Consider other depictions of this painting and how Manet's depiction becomes absurd:[image]Done, The Downgrading of Olympia (2014)[image]Nancy Ellison, Hume Cronyn (as Manet’s Olympia), (1990)Nonetheless, not all depictions of Black slaves were made ridiculous – or invisible:[image] Edward Troye, Richard Singleton with Viley’s Harry, Charles and Lew, (1834)Geraldine Brooks seems to talk about two kinds of barriers to understanding: seeing the horse or person as a unique individual, but also misunderstanding the implications behind words and behaviors. Why would Jarrett like the dirty and noisy city as opposed to returning to be Alexander's Jarrett? "Their hands is their own. And that dollar that get put in those hands, that’s their own dollar" (pp. 263-264). These simple – and fundamental – misunderstandings often had significant implications, some of which were not much different today than in the 19th century US.One of the brilliant things about Horse is that most of the historical figures – and all of the horses – were real, although many stories about their lives were imagined. That underlying truth connecting the three stories adds an additional layer of mystery and glitter. And, the stories I've focused on here both connect with and are only a small aspect of the stories that Brooks tells in Horse....more

review: Maus: A Survivor's Tale is the story of the author's father's life during WWII, attempting to evade the Nazis. Unless you are a Holocaust denier, you Maus: A Survivor's Tale is the story of the author's father's life during WWII, attempting to evade the Nazis. Unless you are a Holocaust denier, you already know the general outline of his father's story: working the black market in order to support his family, hiding from the Nazis, fighting in the war and becoming a prisoner of war, moving from city to city, attempting to find safety, attempting to pass as a Pole to travel or work safely.[image]p. 8Told as a graphic novel, with Jews drawn as mice, Poles as pigs, and Nazis cats, Maus could easily flatten or idealize/demonize the father's story and the Holocaust. Instead, Art Spiegelman includes small details that prevent us from backing away from the Jews' humanity: his father's courtship of his mother; their attempt to save his older brother, which unknowingly sent him to his death; their dinners of the entire family, many in denial about the danger they faced (even as they were hiding in a small apartment).[image]p. 125The Holocaust period was presented against the backdrop of their current lives: his father's miserly behaviors, suspiciousness, and irritability; his stepmother's complaints about her husband; and his search for information about his mother, who committed suicide in 1968. These behaviors contrasted with his story of the war, where he was a compassionate and considerate husband. Did the father omit the behaviors that the son saw or were they the consequence of the war and life or both? Just as his father was presented warts and all, the author did not shy away from showing his own frustrations with his father, even calling his father a murderer at one point (his father had burned his mother's diaries after her death). Again, this led to the narrative's credibility, as did his father's use of idiomatic English and the drawings, which were simple but compelling.em>Maus was published in two volumes, this one ending with his parents' capture by the Nazis, where they were sent to Auschwitz and Birkenau....more

Often mysteries ignore the impact crime has on people other than the immediate victim. Hidden in Snow begins to remedy this oversight.[image]Sweden, with the story's major locations in red and greenOne of the things that I liked about this book was its characters' frequent omissions of relevant information during interviews: "Harald wonders whether he ought to mention the tense atmosphere between them, but decides against it" (p. 85). I wonder how police officers ever get sufficiently reliable interview information given our tendency to present ourselves in the best light, because we don't realize that something is important, because we don't like – or do like – the interviewer, because we misremember the relevant events.I read Hidden in Snow after a deep freeze here. We whined about -5ºF temperatures and high winds, about our sunrise at 7:45am, and sunset at 5pm. The events taking place in this book account for most of the emotional reactions in this book, but today's sunrise in Åre, Sweden is 9:48am, sunset at 2:33pm. This shortened day – 4 ½ hours – surely accounts for some of the book's rampant depression, anger, and alcohol abuse, which both precede and follow the crimes.And, of course, sunny, cooperative characters don't fit neatly in most mysteries....more

my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: "The edge is a shantytown filled with gold seekers. We are fugitives, and the law is skinny with hunger for us." (p. 38)Frankie and Zeke, age 16, crea"The edge is a shantytown filled with gold seekers. We are fugitives, and the law is skinny with hunger for us." (p. 38)Frankie and Zeke, age 16, created a poster with these two sentences and a drawing of two large hands reaching toward a town and the child in it. They hung the poster throughout their community – and it went viral (it was found in other states and countries). Although these two bright but awkward outsiders had no negative intents, we impose meaning. People thought this anonymously-hung poster might contain the lyrics from a heavy metal song, be related to a previously unknown cult, be lines from the Bible, echo street graffiti, or be influenced by artists like Jean-Michel Basquiat and Keith Haring.In other words, people lost it and lost perspective. At least two people died in their town as a result, with others likely elsewhere. Frankie, who narrates Now Is Not the Time to Panic, obsessed over her phrase, but hid her involvement with its creation.So, Now Is Not the Time to Panic is about art and finding meaning in art: “We’d created meaning where there was none, but, I don’t know, isn’t that art? Or at least I think it’s the kind of art that I like, where the obsession of one person envelops other people, transforms them" (p. 47).It is about being a teenager in a small town and feeling invisible and alone: "And he’d sniff and sniff, and I’d pray that he couldn’t smell me, what was underneath all that perfume, because I knew it would smell so desperate, so lonely" (p. 32). I started grabbing anything I could find [to read] and I had no idea what other people thought was good or what was important. And so I almost never told anyone what I liked because I was terrified that they would tell me how stupid it was. Every single thing that you loved became a source of both intense obsession and possible shame. Everything was a secret. (p. 108)But a person can't live this way. When anything/everything can be a source of shame, that damages how you look at yourself and the world: the world is unsafe and the self is unworthy. So Now Is Not the Time to Panic is also about trauma. Frankie struggles with whether she is a good person despite their poster causing several deaths. She obsesses about the poster, but also hides her knowledge of it and is afraid of being judged, but ultimately recognizes that speaking aloud about it will set her free and, rather than interfering with her relationships, may strengthen them.I may be imposing this last view on Now Is Not the Time to Panic, having also read Kevin Wilson's Nothing to See Here, which I loved (but I love this more). Both books speak in metaphors and edge on fantasy, but Now Is Not the Time to Panic is more realistic, which I think makes it more powerful.I need more Kevin Wilson in my life....more

review: Mayo Clinic Guide to Fibromyalgia is comprehensive rather than only anecdotal in its approach, which makes it more useful than some books on fibromyalMayo Clinic Guide to Fibromyalgia is comprehensive rather than only anecdotal in its approach, which makes it more useful than some books on fibromyalgia, but it tends to be vague and repetitive. The good thing is that people experiencing fibro fog – and those who need to make a significant shift in their thinking about fibromyalgia – are repeatedly reminded that there are things that they can do. Unfortunately, this book could be a pamphlet, maybe several pamphlets, with no loss to the consumer.So, if you're wondering whether you can do anything to handle the pain, here's the skinny: medications can be helpful but also have significant downsides. Massage works short-term but does not seem to have long-last effects. What seems to be helpful is Cognitive Behavioral Therapy, moderation and pacing of physical activity, reducing stress and resolving depression, social support, stretching, and setting reasonable goals. Partnering with your medical team – and your family – is very important. And, bottom line, these suggestions are much the same as those given for any chronic pain problem. Pain can be handled well. That doesn't mean that pain is easy to handle, just that it does not need to take over a person's life. There are things you can do....more

title: The Body Keeps the Score: Brain, Mind, and Body in the Healing of Trauma
author: Kolk, Bessel van der
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: We ignore trauma and fail to recognize it when we can. In the US, we identified and prevented animal abuse before abuse against children. The first USWe ignore trauma and fail to recognize it when we can. In the US, we identified and prevented animal abuse before abuse against children. The first US state law against animal cruelty was passed in New York in 1828, while child maltreatment only became a growing social concern in the 1960s. There is still no specific law outlawing domestic violence in 49 countries, no legislation addressing sexual harassment in 45, and nothing criminalizing marital rape in 112 countries. Not seeing trauma or recognizing its impact is a big thing. As a result, trauma sequelae are seen as senseless and the people who are acting out – for trauma-related reasons – are seen as crazy or bad. People who are traumatized are often given a series of diagnoses rather than having the deeper core of their pain recognized. Many are given a diagnosis that sounds like a disease state but misses (and obscures) the underlying cause, trauma. Staff discussions on the unit rarely mentioned the horrific real-life experiences of the children and the impact of those traumas on their feelings, thinking, and self-regulation. Instead, their medical records were filled with diagnostic labels: “conduct disorder” or “oppositional defiant disorder” for the angry and rebellious kids; or “bipolar disorder.” ADHD was a “comorbid” diagnosis for almost all. Was the underlying trauma being obscured by this blizzard of diagnoses? (p. 169)Failures to recognize trauma and using the disease model to describe symptoms subverts control over a person’s life, taking it "out of their own hands and [putting] doctors and insurance companies in charge of fixing their problems" (p. 68). Trauma changes everything. Being hurt by a caregiver, for example, affects many people's ability to recognize and maintain safe relationships, their ability to trust others, and beliefs that they deserve to be kept safe. After a history of sexual abuse, how do children become able to trust their bodies or themselves?Agencies and practitioners talk about trauma-informed care – almost 60 years after we finally acknowledged that child abuse is real. All care should be trauma-informed; yet, agencies and practitioners still ignore/fail to recognize the impact of trauma. Given this, The Body Keeps the Score fills an important role. Bessel van der Kolk's description of trauma is clear and accessible to a lay population and describes many ways that a range of traumas can affect a person. On the other hand, The Body Keeps the Score feels flabby and would probably be more useful as two much shorter books. One-third of the book describes a series of somatic therapies; it might be more useful to say that any intervention that presents a corrective emotional experience (rather than only a cognitive one) is helpful – and make this section a second book. What do I know, though? The Body Keeps the Score has consistently had a waitlist of a month or more at my local library – eight years after it was first published!...more
